answer: The author concludes the story in this way because gardens cannot thrive when the ground is covered with snow. Hope, a fresh start, and adaptation are the reasons the speaker concludes by stating, "When they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author indicates that she will do nothing until the weather outside is pleasant. She desires a temperature that is neither too cold nor too hot so that she can go out and play with her children. Additionally, she mentions that she will retake the test when the weather is nice for her.

The author concludes the story in this way to demonstrate that Saeng is extremely enthusiastic about bridging her life in the United States with her life in Vietnam and integrating the two somehow. The author might have ended the story this way because it represents a downfall. This implies that the character is currently at the bottom and must work their way to the top. They are going to start anew and retake the test, but this time, they are determined not to fail.

The author concluded the paragraph in this manner to evoke emotion. The last paragraph conveys the sadness of not being able to garden during winter, when all of her plants die for the season. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate how Saeng has learned from the hibiscus plant. Similar to the plant, Saeng will overcome an obstacle. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it shows that Saeng will accept her new home, recognize the similarities to her old home, and cherish memories to help her overcome life's obstacles. The author ends the story in this way to demonstrate the similarity between Saeng and the hibiscus plant and how Saeng will overcome her obstacle when the plant overcomes its own. @CAPS2, memories, and hard @CAPS1 are all reasons for the author to conclude the story with “When They come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, Then I will take the test again.” First, @CAPS2 is involved because Saeng failed her test initially, and it takes courage and will - power to go back and attempt it again. The author includes the last paragraph to illustrate that Saeng still holds hope. In “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with a specific paragraph to reinforce the theme of adapting to new circumstances and making the most of each change, while also ending on a hopeful note. The statement “Saeng vowed silently to herself” indicates Saeng's effort to integrate into her new life and find its positive aspects. I believe the author ends the story with that statement so the audience can compare Saeng to the hibiscus. After reading it, I noticed that Saeng and the hibiscus are similar as they'll both persevere and succeed (Saeng getting her license and the hibiscus blooming). The author might have used this ending to show Saeng's commitment to her goal and her refusal to give up, as shown when “Saeng vowed silently to herself, ‘I will take that test again’.” Finally, I think the ending gives the audience a sense of what will happen to Saeng while leaving some room for interpretation. For example, I'm confident Saeng will retake and pass the test, but another reader might think she'll fail again and have to retake it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to enable the reader to draw parallels between the girl, the geese, and the hibiscus. The geese migrate in winter and return in spring, mirroring the girl's intention to retake the driver's test in spring. The hibiscus withers in winter and begins to bud again in spring, indicating that winter is its vulnerable period. Similarly, the girl overcomes her driving weakness by recalling her homeland. By placing this paragraph at the end, the author shows that the girl shares similarities with the geese and the hibiscus.

I think the author ended the story with that phrase to demonstrate the main character's maturation. She admits she wasn't prepared for the challenges ahead. For instance, when she failed her test, instead of being distraught, she simply said she'd take it again next year. Throughout the story, she yearned for her homeland and coped by buying a winter hibiscus, which reminded her of both her homeland and her grandmother. Overall, the main character displayed depth and maturity in the story.

The author concludes the story in this way to illustrate Saeng's willingness to adapt to her environment, much like the hibiscus. Saeng must adjust to her new home in @LOCATION1, and the hibiscus must adapt to the approaching winter. Saeng vows, “When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding...” From this, it's evident that Saeng holds hope for both herself and the hibiscus. Initially, Saeng was hesitant to accept her new home, commenting that “it’s not like the kind we had before” about the hibiscus. However, she realized that the hibiscus could serve as a reminder of home and a prompt to adapt to her new surroundings. She understood that if the hibiscus could survive the winter, she could thrive in a new place.

The author concludes the story with Saeng's silent vow to retake the test in spring. Saeng struggles to adapt to her new home and refuses to quit after a single failure. When spring arrives, with the return of the geese and the blooming of the hibiscus, Saeng will feel ready to take the test again. Spring symbolizes a chance for a new attempt and a fresh start.

The author concludes the story with the last paragraph as it reveals Saeng will retake the test. Earlier, in a paragraph, Saeng told her mother she failed the test. I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph because the plant symbolizes determination to survive. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with this paragraph for several reasons. It shows that Saeng will not give up; she will wait for the next opportunity to take the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it depicts Saeng silently vowing to herself. She is reflecting on events from long ago with her mother and the plants in her garden. The story features @PERSON1, a girl, and her mother. The girl was given money to buy plant seeds and spent @MONEY1 on them. Her mother got upset, but then things turned around, like they had egg omelets with bits of melon. The author concludes the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that after all the events, Saeng will move forward and strive hard. For instance, when Saeng said, “When they come back in the spring, When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Ending the story this way leaves the reader in suspense as they are unsure if the geese will return. The author concluded the story with this paragraph because she can't wait for spring. In spring, her plant will bud, which will remind her of her homeland. I firmly believe there's a significant reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. I think the author will feel more at ease and well - prepared to take the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to demonstrate that she has hope. She believes she can pass the test when everything returns to normal in the spring. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to draw a comparison between Saeng's life and a plant. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate Saeng's determination to adapt to life changes. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the significance of new beginnings and to highlight the story's theme. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” author Minfong Ho concludes the story with that paragraph as a way of suggesting that Saeng will put the past failure of her driving test behind her and strive for better results next time. The hibiscus serves as a thematic element in the story. It inspires the protagonist, evoking memories of her home country and motivating her to explore new experiences. I believe the author chose to conclude the story in this manner to depict the girl reflecting on her past and finding tranquility in the presence of the flower. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that the character is determined to pass the test and will not abandon her efforts until she achieves success. I feel the author ended the story with this paragraph to demonstrate how the character has matured and grown within her circumstances. In the short story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the story concludes with Saeng silently vowing, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again. ‘I - I failed the test’.” Like many children, Saeng failed her driving test and was deeply upset. Failing a test, especially when others have succeeded, can be a humiliating experience. The quotes in the introduction and question are symbolic. The return of the geese north symbolizes a fresh start or a new attempt, while the budding hibiscus represents the renewal of life. Saeng, observing these natural cycles of renewal, is empowered to persevere and try again. She realizes that failure is a part of life and that success requires perseverance. Minfong Ho concludes with this quote to convey that regardless of the obstacles, one must keep pressing forward and working hard. Success is the result of dedication and commitment, qualities that define a strong individual.

The author concludes the paragraph with that sentence to convey to the reader that the situation is not over. The author intends for the reader to understand that @ORGANIZATION1 will not forget and that all these events will recur.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with the line “I will take that test again,” indicating that the challenges the protagonist, Saeng, is facing will repeat, but she will be better prepared next time. Saeng struggles to adapt when moving to another country. Her mother supports her through the difficult winter. The hibiscus she bought during her toughest time symbolizes more than itself. In the last paragraph, when she says, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” she is looking forward to the future. Saeng silently vows to herself in the spring, eagerly awaiting the end of winter and the arrival of spring.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to inform the readers about what she will do upon her return in spring. Specifically, she will take care of the plants. The author also implies that she hopes the snow will melt and normalcy will return when she gets back. This is the message the author conveys through the story.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to reassure the reader that the character will return. The author concludes the story with this paragraph either to entice the readers to purchase his upcoming book or to heighten their excitement for future works.

In this story, the author decides to conclude with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is because she wishes to take the test when everything is ideal. For instance, she desires elements she likes in her environment, such as the flowers, the geese, and the weather. Another reason the author ends the story with this paragraph is that she wants to be in an environment similar to that of her home - country. For example, there was no snow there, and it was like spring all year round. This is the rationale behind the author's choice to end the story with that paragraph.

The author ends the story with a particular paragraph to convey that the character is consoled by the memories of her homeland and highly appreciates the beauty of tropical plants. The character believes that since it is winter and the hibiscus is not budding, she cannot pass the test until it does. The statement “almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now” demonstrates her strong belief in the beauty of her homeland and tropical plants. She reflects on past times when things were strange in winter and better in spring and other seasons when the plants were budding. Thus, she believes she will pass the driver's test when she feels comfortable, that is, when the plants have budded.

The migration of geese flying south for winter and the budding of hibiscus are familiar and normal occurrences for Saeng. The author concludes the story in this way to illustrate that Saeng finds comfort in familiar things. Saeng hopes to have the geese and hibiscus present to feel more at ease while taking her driving test. She still yearns for her home in Vietnam and doesn't fully feel like she belongs in the U.S. The hibiscus gives her a sense of comfort, as if she is back home. Her homesickness stems from her desire for things to be as they were. The plants in the greenhouse and the disappointment of failing her driving test contribute to her emotional state. In the second - last paragraph, the author describes Saeng's feeling of repetition when seeing the geese in a V - formation. Saeng feels that in winter, she won't have the same comfort as when she can see the hibiscus and geese overhead. When she arrived at the location, she had nothing familiar to her, but now she gets that feeling from the geese and plants. The author's conclusion that Saeng will take her driving test when winter ends is a fitting closure as it provides insight into her future actions.

I believe the reason the author concludes with the sentence “When they come back, Saeng vowed to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” is that it was winter and the school was closed. When the geese return, it will be spring, and that will be the time to go back to school. This, in my opinion, is the underlying reason for this conclusion.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends the story in an unusual way. The line “‘when they come back,’ Saeng vowed silently to herself, ‘in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding. then I will take that test again.’” Beyond its literal meaning, I think the author is showing how Saeng is adapting to the new country. Failing her driver's test implies that she has yet to fully adapt and accept the new country. However, by vowing to try again, she shows her willingness to give the country another chance. The statement “She found she was still too shaky to say the words at home” indicates that she still doesn't consider this country her home and is still attached to her past. Overall, the ending effectively portrays Saeng's complex journey of adaptation.

In the paragraph, the author concludes the story to illustrate that Saeng will not cease her efforts merely because she failed once. It also demonstrates that she will not allow certain circumstances to discourage her.

I firmly believe the last sentence of a story often holds the most significance. In this case, the author chose to end the story in a particular way for multiple reasons. Firstly, the author aimed to leave the reader with a powerful sense of determination. The story quotes, “I will take that test again.” The use of the word “will” clearly showcases the girl's unwavering resolve. She didn't say she would attempt it; she stated with absolute certainty that she will. Secondly, the author ended the story this way to emphasize the theme of new beginnings. The quote, “when they come back... in the spring... I will take that test again” indicates that in spring, the season of new life, she will take the test. All in all, these are the reasons why I believe the author ended the story as such.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” made a prudent decision by concluding the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This passage subtly suggests to the reader that Saeng intends to integrate her old and new lives. The hibiscus represents her old life, as she is accustomed to the constants from her homeland. The geese symbolize her new life, having become “almost familiar to her now.” The driving test is the obstacle she must overcome. The author implies that in spring, when the old and new aspects of Saeng's life merge, she will be able to surmount her “obstacle,” and everything will fall into place. With the geese on the ground, Saeng's life will have come full circle.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it is crucial when Saeng says that when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again. This informs the reader of the time when she will retake the test, which is why it is included in the story.

In Minfong Ho's “Winter Hibiscus,” I am of the opinion that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it emphasizes Saeng's willingness to retake the test when the appropriate time arrives. Additionally, the second - last paragraph in the story states, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of the season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This sentence shows me that Saeng is gradually adapting to the new place. It also reveals how she is changing her perspective on the plant, understanding that even though it is different from what she's used to, it can still hold meaning. Consequently, I believe the author made an excellent choice in ending the story with this paragraph.

The final paragraph reads, "In the spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." It is believed that the author ended with this paragraph to convey that when her new home resembles her old one, she may feel more confident and at ease. This is in contrast to the cold winter, which is the opposite of her former living environment. The sense of her old home within her new one will make her more positive and comfortable. Consequently, she will take the test feeling at home and is likely to pass.

In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the author portrays how the girl, Saeng, believes that with her memories and after adapting to the new culture, she will gain the courage to retake the test she failed. Saeng misses her home deeply and initially fails to recognize the similarities between her new and old homes. As the text states, "She realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." Although Saeng did not anticipate the move, she starts to create new memories while holding onto the old ones. At first, everything was extremely different, but now she is beginning to recall aspects of her new home, which brings her comfort. For instance, "She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again." The ending paragraph indicates that there is hope for Saeng to move forward in her new home. She is gradually gaining confidence and knows that when she does, she can take the test and succeed. The author demonstrates that positive change is possible if one is willing to adapt. Not everything may be as perfect as one expects, but courage can help create a happy home filled with both new and old memories, as Saeng realizes in the last paragraph.

In this short story, the author simply states the obvious. The excerpt mainly implies that when spring arrives, the girl will return to the greenhouse or the area full of plants. I believe the author concludes the story with that particular paragraph to depict Saeng as a person who never gives up and keeps growing, much like the hibiscus plant. Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph to convey Saeng's feelings. This ending makes the reader think about Saeng's determination and her ability to face challenges. The author concludes the story in this manner to illustrate that a happy ending is always possible. The return of the geese brought happiness to the girl. This outcome showcases the potential for positive resolutions within the narrative.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph as the character is not willing to give up on certain things. Saeng feels more at ease in the spring as it evokes memories of her home. Having perhaps never experienced snow or winter before, the winter season fails to remind her of home. In spring, the return of the geese and the regrowth of hibiscus make everything feel like home again. The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with that paragraph as it encapsulates the strength and courage the hibiscus has provided to Saeng. When the author writes, “In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it symbolizes Saeng opening her mind to new ways, such as learning to drive, highlighting the theme of growth and adaptation in the story.

I think the author of “Winter Hibiscus” chose that as the last paragraph because seeing the hibiscus will bring back memories of home, which will encourage her for the test. The author concludes the text with that paragraph as it subtly conveys the message that everything will turn out fine. The author uses this paragraph to conclude the story as it illustrates Saeng's desire to adapt to the country and her growing understanding and fondness for it. When the text states, "and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," it serves as a metaphor for Saeng herself. Just as the hibiscus begins to bloom and thrive, Saeng too is starting to bloom and progress. This is the rationale behind the author ending the story with this passage.

Saeng stated that she will retake the test when the tree she purchased starts budding. What she means is that without that plant, she lacks the motivation to take the test. This is because the plant has been with her throughout her life. She also believes that she cannot succeed without it. In my opinion, while Saeng thinks she needs the plant due to its long - standing presence in her life, she may not actually require it. I suppose it simply provides her with a sense of comfort.

Initially, the author did not think Saeng was ready to take the test until she had more knowledge about it. It is a positive thing that Saeng made a vow to take the test because otherwise, she would never know if she would perform well or poorly. Eventually, the author came to the realization that Saeng will take the test and pass.

The author concludes the text with this paragraph mainly to emphasize her memories of her homeland. By stating that she will take the driving test again next spring, she acknowledges that the arrival of spring will bring back a multitude of memories. During spring, animals emerge and trees blossom, creating a beautiful setting. This beauty, combined with the support of her memories of her country, makes it an ideal time for her to retake the test. This is why the author chose this ending.

After reading Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story in a distinct manner that showcases a will to survive. For instance, in the text, the author describes how the "dok faeng - noi" plants have adapted to their cold environment, which differs from their native one. This exemplifies the concept of survival as these plants migrated to a seemingly warm place in the past. When the cold set in, they found ways to transform and adapt, all driven by the instinct to survive. Another example from the text is Saeng telling herself that she will retake the test in spring. This demonstrates her will to survive because after failing the test, she felt a sense of melancholy and failure. The fact that she has the courage to prepare for the test in spring shows that as a human being, she wants to live. To thrive in a new country, she must adapt by passing that test and becoming a survivor.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph about snow on the roads. Through this, the author shows people the importance of watching where they are going. Ultimately, the paragraph indicates that the protagonist made it through the snowstorm, highlighting the successful navigation through the challenging situation.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Saeng vows to herself that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus brings Saeng comfort and confidence, making her feel at home. The quote "Almost familiar to her now" from the story shows that things are starting to fall into place for her. It makes her realize that her current living place can be similar to her former home. The hibiscus also brings back memories of the flowers they had in their previous residence. Both the mother and the daughter appreciate the flower they found as it resembles the one they had back home. For example, the mother says, "Its flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months here." This demonstrates their appreciation for its similarity to the old hibiscus. In conclusion, the author ends the story with this paragraph to help readers understand the significance of the girl's memories of her former home.

The author chose this ending to show that Saeng hasn't given up on her new life. Even though she deeply loved her hometown and has many fond memories of it, taking the test and failing added a great deal of pressure to her new life. Although she hasn't fully adapted, she will do her best to overcome the challenges that come her way. Ending the story like this gives the reader hope, rather than leaving them with the impression that Saeng simply bought a flower after failing a test and moved on. In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by @CAPS1 Ho, the author concludes with Saeng silently vowing, “When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This serves as a symbol of hope for the reader. When the geese return and the hibiscus blooms, Saeng will feel more at ease as she has adapted to the new place and made new acquaintances. The blooming hibiscus will evoke fond memories of her homeland. This will assist Saeng in achieving her goal of passing the test. I believe the author ended the story this way to entice readers to reread it or recommend it to others. I dislike stories that end abruptly without revealing what happens next, but the author addressed this by letting us know that Saeng will try again to pass the test.

The final paragraph of “Winter Hibiscus” states, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ends the story with this to convey that Saeng has hope and will continue to adapt to her new life in @LOCATION2 @CAPS1. In the story, Saeng realizes she is not as far from her Vietnamese home as she thought. In the florist shops, plants she had forgotten about brought back childhood memories. The plants from her homeland also exist in @LOCATION2. She fails “the test” by buying a winter hibiscus after a bout of homesickness. By the story's end, she recognizes that she is getting used to her new life, like the sight of geese flying overhead. The statement in the last paragraph implies that by spring, she hopes to overcome homesickness and consider @LOCATION2, with its geese and winter hibiscuses, as her home.

The author concludes the story in this manner to illustrate Saeng's newly - found determination. The entire story chronicles Saeng's journey during one afternoon to come to terms with her new home. Thus, it is appropriate to end with Saeng's resolve to pass her driving test and make a life in @LOCATION1. The story explores several elements that make Saeng feel at home, such as the sharp bitter melon and the hibiscus. These elements lead Saeng to feel more at ease in her new environment, making it fitting to end with her acceptance of staying in @LOCATION1. @PERSON1 is also inspired by the hibiscus, which is “strong enough to make it through the cold months; that’s what matters.” This reflects Saeng's determination to adapt to her new life. Finally, when Saeng recognizes that life in @LOCATION1 is becoming “familiar” through the geese, it leads @PERSON1 to realize that this is her new home and she cannot go back. The story is replete with events like these that contribute to Saeng's determination, so concluding with her determination is a suitable ending.

The author includes this paragraph at the end of the story because it symbolizes a new beginning. For instance, the family's move to a different country represents a fresh start. When the author mentions the arrival of spring, it symbolizes a new life, which is exactly what Saeng and her mother are embarking on. The snow acts as a blanket over the past and hard times. Additionally, when the hibiscus starts to bud, it also signifies a new beginning. When all these symbols are combined, they show that the hard times fade away as the snow melts, and a new beginning emerges with the arrival of spring and the budding of the flower. This is why the author included this paragraph, as the characters needed a fresh start.

The author chose that sentence as the concluding one because Saeng believes she deserves another opportunity to take the garden test. This conclusion reflects Saeng's growth and her determination to improve her situation.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” penned by Minfong Ho, a teenage girl named Saeng and her family have relocated from Vietnam to the United States. After failing her driver's test, Saeng is walking home. Along the way, she spots a familiar plant and then enters a florist shop to buy it. When she gets home, she tells her mother about the failed test. Naturally, her mother is disappointed, but she still makes dinner. The plant in question is the “winter hibiscus”. At the end of the story, Saeng thinks to herself, “when they come back, in spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. It seems that Saeng decides to retake the test in spring because she now feels confident and content. She has grown comfortable with the plant, and her mother isn't overly angry. She believes that everything will work out and that spring, a time of new beginnings, is the right moment to try again.

The author concludes the story with this line as it demonstrates that the geese drew inspiration from the flower to return, persevere, and not give up. Just like the geese and the hibiscus, she will come back. That is why the author chose to end the story with this line, aiming to show Saeng's inspiration and her refusal to quit.

In my opinion, in the short - story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author ends with that paragraph to illustrate Saeng's determination to pass. The entire story of Saeng purchasing the hibiscus stems from her failure in the driving test, which deeply crushed her. Minfong Ho, the author of “Winter Hibiscus,” ended the story with the last paragraph because in the story, the girl took a test (the nature of which is unknown) and failed. Her mother asked why she spent so much money on the plant when she could have bought a Big Mac, their favorite fast - food sandwich. She wants to try again and says, “Then the snow will melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will return to take the test again.” She believes that next time, she will pass the test, avoid shame, and make her parents proud. In Vietnam, few people drive, and it is a high honor for the family for their daughter to achieve this.

After recently relocating from Vietnam, Saeng is clearly grappling with homesickness. In my opinion, the author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to illustrate a sense of change in her. As Saeng's mother mentioned, winter is harsh, but spring is when everything comes to life. In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng and her mother move to a new place, and Saeng struggles to adapt. A passage from the text, "Almost reluctantly, she realised that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before, through that quiet repetition of season upon season, were almost familiar to her now" (Ho @NUM1), demonstrates the narrator's hope. This shows that she recognized that many things that once seemed purposeless now had meaning. She understood that spring symbolizes a new beginning. The conclusion states that she will retake the test in spring, indicating her awareness of the new opportunity and life ahead. In summary, the conclusion of "Winter Hibiscus" reflects the realization of the opportunities that spring presents.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate the motivation and confidence Saeng gains from her experience with the plant. There are multiple reasons and examples to support this. Firstly, it shows the transformation in Saeng from after her first test to when she bought the flower for comfort. For instance, after failing the driving test, Saeng visits the florist. When she sees the plant, memories of her childhood resurface, and she forgets about the test. The flower inspires her to obtain her license. Secondly, it demonstrates the confidence this experience has instilled in her. After the failure, she declares, "I will take the test again." In conclusion, the author includes this paragraph to showcase how Saeng has grown more confident through her experience.

The author concludes the story with this statement to illustrate that Saeng, like the hibiscus, will not give up. The hibiscus endures the harsh winter conditions and blooms anew in spring, symbolizing a fresh start. Similarly, Saeng will persevere through her difficulties and retake the test in spring. The author aims to convey to readers that Saeng and the hibiscus share a parallel in that they both must start over and retry after setbacks, much like the hibiscus seemingly "dies" in winter only to revive in spring. In essence, the author uses this comparison to emphasize Saeng's resilience and determination.

My response is that if a story is about winter, it is likely to involve activities such as walking around and having fun during the winter season. Winter offers unique experiences, like enjoying the snow, the cold air, and the beauty of the season. These activities can bring a sense of joy and adventure. In conclusion, a story about winter would typically revolve around the various enjoyable aspects of this season.

The author concludes the story in such a manner to pique the reader's interest and convey that the events will recur annually. This ending effectively emphasizes the cyclical nature of the narrative, leaving a lasting impression on the reader.

In my view, the author concludes the story with this particular paragraph as it implies that the protagonist will draw strength from the blooming of the flowers and be ready to take the test. The connection between the flowers and her ability to face the challenge adds a symbolic layer to the story's conclusion.

The author concludes the story in this way to symbolize the new beginning that is about to occur. It is as if the character is suggesting that she will endure the hardships of winter, much like nature in hibernation, and when spring arrives with its renewal of life, she too will embark on a fresh start. As Saeng realizes that the once - strange aspects of her life have become familiar through the repeated cycles of seasons, it is evident that the new season will mark a new chapter for her, with a changed perspective on life.

The author ends the story in this fashion to provide a comprehensive conclusion. This use of nature in the conclusion enriches the story's overall atmosphere.

I firmly believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it implies that the character will gain the strength to take the test when the flowers bloom. The flowers serve as a powerful symbol of hope and renewal, suggesting that the character's moment of courage and readiness will coincide with the natural cycle of growth and beauty.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," author Minfong Ho concludes the narrative as such to showcase the determination of the girl in the story. Initially, the girl was unable to resist and purchased the costly flower. However, not wanting to disappoint her mother, she was resolved to "pass the test." Come spring, when it's time to buy more seeds, the girl hopes to be capable of making the purchase. Thus, the author is highlighting the girl's trait of determination.

The author concludes the story with the line “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is because the budding hibiscus symbolizes a fresh start, and Saeng taking the test again represents her opportunity to begin anew and try once more. Just as the hibiscus doesn't cease budding, Saeng should not stop trying.

In the final paragraph of the story, the author concludes it in this manner as the hibiscus serves as a symbol of overcoming obstacles. For instance, Saeng's mother remarks, “Its flowers aren't pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the cold months.” This symbolizes the ability to overcome obstacles, as the flower endures the harsh cold - weather months. In Saeng's situation, she is a girl who will thrive in a foreign country. So, in the last paragraph, when Saeng silently vows to retake the driver's test when the snow melts and the hibiscus is budding, she uses the hibiscus as a symbol of surmounting the obstacle of failing the test. This is the reason the author chose to end the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey Saeng's determination to complete what she started. She failed the driver's test and was extremely disappointed; for example, she began to cry and had “tear stains and puffy eyes” as she recalled her homeland in Vietnam, her life, memories, and family. She can identify with the geese that migrate in winter and return, signifying new beginnings in spring. Just like the blossoming hibiscus represents a fresh start, she aims for a new start with the driver's test.

I believe the author concludes this story with this paragraph to convey the advice that since Saeng didn't give up, neither should others. This paragraph describes a life principle of “never give up.” Despite failing initially, Saeng is still eager to try again, and this is a valuable lesson that the author wants to impart through the story's conclusion.

Saeng silently vowed to herself that when spring arrives, the snows melt, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud, she will retake the test. The inclusion of this in the story by the author is to convey that one should not procrastinate but rather address issues as they arise. In the story, the girl's behavior sets a poor example, and it is evident that the author intended to emphasize the importance of not doing so. Overall, adding this phrase to the story was a prudent choice as it effectively demonstrates the correct approach to handling such matters.

She ought to learn that one cannot replace a plant with an identical one and expect it to be of equal value. This is an important lesson in life that she needs to grasp. By understanding this, she will gain a more realistic perspective on the uniqueness of living things and the irreplaceability of certain experiences.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng will align herself with nature and attempt to integrate into her new land. Saeng failed her driver's test and feels out of place in her new home. The text mentions, “As Saebba nedae tall and lush. And surrounded there garden” (No 1). When she sees the [@CAPS1], it reminds her of her old home where she felt a sense of belonging. Now, she wishes to wait for the flower to grow before retaking the driver's test. Additionally, when she plants her flower, she sees geese flying overhead. The author writes, “…She realized that many of the things that she had thought strange before had become…almost familiar to her how” (No [@NUM1]). The return of the geese in spring will now also remind her of her new name and the need to try to live happily in her new home. In the last paragraph, the author has Saeng say, “I will take that test again” (No [@NUM1]), which gives the impression that Saeng is striving to start anew in this new environment.

This is a potent sentence that showcases the themes in the story. Saeng is resolute in trying again as she has found solace in the symbol of her homeland. The sentence reveals the positive impact the plant has had on Saeng's spirit and how this symbol aids in her emotional healing. It effectively wraps up the story and highlights the significance of the hibiscus. In the story, [@CAPS1] describes the plant as a friend and a reminder of her homeland. Once she witnesses the plant in bloom, she will know that she is ready to retake the test. The paragraph serves as an excellent conclusion to the passage as it summarizes the profound meaning the hibiscus holds for Saeng.

I believe the author aims to convey the message of never giving up and to showcase the beauty of nature. In the story, Saeng fails the test, but the ending indicates that she will take it again. The story also mentions the winter hibiscus she planted, which is addressed in the conclusion. The conclusion essentially implies that there will be a new beginning. This message of hope and perseverance, combined with the imagery of nature, enriches the story and leaves a positive impression on the reader.

The author concluded the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” as the paragraph itself serves as a conclusion. It essentially summarizes what she intends to do once more next time, given that she has already gone through it. The meaning behind this paragraph is that when the plants revive in the spring, she will have to repeat all the work, which is essentially the test.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey to the readers that the protagonist doesn't give up. Some might have thought that she considered the tests back home to be more important. Thus, they might assume that she wouldn't care about passing this test because she misses her home and isn't concerned about these tests. However, the conclusion shows her determination.

I believe the author ends the story in that way as a metaphor to encourage readers to think outside the box. Alternatively, the author might have ended it like this so that readers can form a mental image of what the author is describing. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to provide the reader with an understanding of how the character feels about what has happened to her. By concluding the story with this paragraph, the author makes Saeng appear more confident in herself. Earlier in the story, during her conversation with her mother, Saeng seemed unsure of herself. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” I think the author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because the author makes Saeng realize that if the hibiscus can restart and bloom anew, she should do the same. This is why the author included this quote at the end of the story, to inspire a sense of renewal and determination in the character.

At the start of the story, Saeng failed her driver's test. Subsequently, she came across a hibiscus plant and purchased it as it evoked memories of her life in Vietnam. As she inhaled, "The familiar fragrance filled her lungs and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long grey hair," which indicated that the flower reminded her of her grandmother. Her mother remarked, "Seen this kind blooming along the lake, its flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make through the cold months," attempting to comfort her daughter. Later, "Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their fault honks clear and now familiar to Saeng. She realized that many of the things that she had once regarded as strange had become almost familiar to her." This shows her gradual adaptation.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because, by the end, the protagonist realizes that the things that once seemed strange are changing with the seasons and the plants. The author included this paragraph at the end as the protagonist plans to return to school in spring to retake the test. This conclusion ties together the themes of change and new beginnings.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story in this way because it symbolizes that when the protagonist found the plant, it foreshadowed her obtaining her license. The plant serves as a reminder for her. Additionally, just as the plant blooms anew each time, when the protagonist decides to take another chance at the test, she is starting afresh. This ending effectively conveys the message of hope and renewal.

I believe the author ends the story with that paragraph to show that the peace the flower brings will boost the protagonist's confidence and prevent her from giving up. The author concludes the story with this ending paragraph as it combines two imperfect situations. The author indicates that she will take the test in the spring rather than the winter. This is because in spring, she can focus solely on the test without being distracted by planting activities.

I believe the author ended the story in this way as throughout the entire narrative, the protagonist strives to work hard. In the story, the author concludes as she does because it is metaphorical. She compares herself to the hibiscus plant. The concluding paragraph of "Winter Hibiscus" conveys a powerful message of transformation from a state of cold, distant failure to adapt to a new life. The author concludes the story this way because it has the greatest impact and offers the most meaning. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the ending “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” is significant. The author concludes the story with the given paragraph as it demonstrates that Saeng realizes her connection to the hibiscus plant. She vows that in spring, when the hibiscus starts budding (restarting its growth cycle), she will restart and retake the test, signifying her determination to adapt and move forward.

In Minfong Ho's “Winter Hibiscus,” the author's final paragraph highlights the significance of the hibiscus. The author employs symbolism when discussing the hibiscus, as it is a resilient plant, much like the girl needs to be to pass the driving test. Placing this paragraph at the end shows that if the hibiscus can rebound after winter, so can the girl. In conclusion, the author uses the last paragraph to emphasize the symbolic meaning of the hibiscus, which represents hope and resilience.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” is filled with emotion and homesickness, making it somewhat depressing. Thus, the author chose to end with a message of hope. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it comprehensively explains the ending. It reveals that the protagonist is willing to invest time in studying for the test she previously failed and intends to retake it once spring arrives. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate the growth or hope within Saeng, indicating that she will eventually feel at ease in the United States. In Minfong Ho's story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.” This shows that one should fight for what is right and what one believes in.

Saeng aimed to demonstrate her strength and determination. Despite losing much hope after moving to another country, she sought to make the best of her situation. The winter intensified her longing for home, leading her to buy a flower as a way to connect with her roots. Come spring, she plans to rejuvenate with the blooming flower and retake the test. This new place with its new hibiscus is now her home, and as winter is not the season for a flower to thrive, she awaits the right time.

Saeng felt a sense of filling in a void by buying something that both comforted her and made her miss her homeland. Her mother was a bit annoyed because of the money she spent. Nevertheless, Saeng silently vowed to herself that in the spring, she would take the test again.

The author concludes the story at this point as it leaves the reader speculating about the subsequent events. Saeng, a girl, feels like an outsider in her new home and country. She silently vows that in a year, she will retake the test. The author may have concluded the story with this paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng is not inclined to stop trying but rather to work harder. In my opinion, the author ends the story with this paragraph because she wants to take the test at a time when it won't be as difficult for her. The weather will be warm again, and it won't be as cold, which will make the test - taking experience more bearable.

The story concludes with this paragraph due to several factors. Firstly, the spring season, with its warm and sunny weather, allows the story to end on a positive note. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that if others can adapt, so can she. This shows that she should be capable of adapting to a new place, similar to how these elements readjust to their cycle.

Authors frequently conclude stories with paragraphs that leave readers pondering what follows next. In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, there is an ending paragraph of this nature. The author ends the story in this way as she is looking forward to the future. She states that she will take the test when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus blooms, viewing it as a new beginning and desiring to start afresh. The presence of the geese, the blooming hibiscus, and the melted snow offer her hope that she will pass the test. She believes that having a hibiscus might make the new place more like her former home. Authors use such endings to prompt readers to think.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to enable readers to understand the events in the story. For instance, when it is stated that “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it is an attempt to gauge the characters' perspectives in the story so that readers can comprehend what the author is conveying.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph because both the geese and the hibiscus are familiar to Saeng. They evoke memories of her homeland. When these familiar elements return, she will gain the strength to retake the test and hopefully achieve better results. The narrator mentions “Overhead a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and - yes - familiar to Saeng now,” which demonstrates that the geese symbolize the familiar aspects of her homeland that help Saeng feel more at ease in her new home.

The author included that paragraph because the hibiscus plant evokes memories of her homeland and aids her in achieving certain things. She misses her home, and this plant helps her recall the memories of being there. Thus, the author included that paragraph to convey to the reader her longing for her homeland.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph that poses the question of why @CAPS1 might be significant to the author in relation to Saeng. The author concludes the story by having Saeng silently vow to herself, "When they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." The author concludes the story in this way for several reasons. To overcome her test failure, Saeng bought a flower that reminded her of home and began to cry, longing to be back. The author concludes the story with Saeng saying to herself, "When the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." These elements make her feel at home, and this sense of comfort will assist her in the test. The conclusion includes all the things that make her comfortable, helping the reader understand what reminds her of home and the significance of the hibiscus flower. Buying the flower alleviates her troubles, and seeing the geese fly evokes memories of her home. The author concludes with these memories, which will support Saeng in the future.

I believe the author ended the story with this conclusion because everyone deserves fresh starts and second chances. The author seems to be conveying the message that if one fails, they should at least try again. When Saeng failed the test, her self - esteem dropped. Her mother tried to cheer her up, and eventually, Saeng realized that giving up without a fresh attempt would be a bad choice.

Minfong Ho incorporated the last paragraph in the story as it implied that Saeng felt better and more confident when reminded of home. When Saeng saw the hibiscus, she experienced a feeling “so intense, it was almost visceral.” Ho creatively utilized the flower. She mentioned that the winter hibiscus is robust enough to endure the cold months, leading readers, after reading the last paragraph, to think that this flower must offer Saeng hope and confidence. Additionally, the geese forming a V likely symbolizes Vietnam to Saeng, which is what the author intends for readers to consider. This is why “and the geese return” is mentioned in the last paragraph. Minfong Ho aims for readers to recognize that objects that bring comfort and happiness ultimately make us strong and confident. The author effectively placed this final thought in the last paragraph as it perfectly encapsulates the lesson: one should act when feeling confident and at home. One may be small and fragile, but if they “plant” themselves, they can thrive with confidence.

The last paragraph of the story serves as the author's means of demonstrating that Saeng wishes for spring to arrive early so she can see her hibiscus. If spring is delayed, she won't be able to see the hibiscus, and the snow won't melt. When Saeng wakes up, she hopes to take the test. In essence, the author uses this to show Saeng's anticipation and connection to the hibiscus and the hope it brings for her test - taking opportunity.

The author concludes the story with the sentence “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” because the winter hibiscus symbolizes a new beginning for her. In her hometown, she had hibiscus plants, and life was normal and fine. However, after moving to the U.S., she lacked hibiscus, failed her driving test, felt out of place, and didn't fit in. When she saw the winter hibiscus, she felt as if she'd found something to make her feel at home or at ease. She experienced a sense of security. In conclusion, the author ended with that sentence as it represents a new start for Saeng, and the hibiscus is a powerful symbol of this fresh beginning.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it parallels her own life, suggesting that she will have another chance, just as geese return. The last part relates to her life as it mentions spring. Spring is typically a favorable time of the year as it gets warmer towards a certain date, and flowers reappear. The hibiscus plant will bloom again, renewing, in a way, her warm memories of her old home. This will be the time for her to retake the driving test she failed before buying the plant. The author added this last part because it aligns so well with the story, enhancing its overall coherence and message.

The author concludes the story with a single short paragraph because sometimes, the little things matter most. The author believed that in just two sentences, they could summarize the most important aspects of the story. In my opinion, the author did an excellent job. By condensing the key points into a concise paragraph, the author effectively emphasizes the significance of these details and leaves a lasting impression on the reader.

The author concludes this paragraph as Saeng has to retake the test. She believes there is a better chance when the hibiscus blooms and the snow melts. Thus, Saeng will attempt the test after the snow has melted and the hibiscus has blossomed.

The author concludes with this sentence for several reasons. Saeng believes she cannot succeed until spring, when the geese return and the hibiscus buds. In a sense, she feels that she will also bloom in spring and be capable of passing the test.

I believe the author includes this paragraph in the story because the grandmother might view it as a test to see what she can accomplish within a certain time. The grandmother might even achieve more than expected.

I think the author concludes the story in this way because perhaps by that time, she'll be ready to retake the test. Another perspective is that when spring arrives, she will be better - prepared and more self - confident. Maybe the author is suggesting that just like the start of a new spring, it will be a new beginning for her.

I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng states she will try again. For instance, after failing her driving test, she decides to retake it after the experience of planting with her mother. Planting the hibiscus seems to have given her the confidence to strive for success once more. In the story, she appeared to be getting accustomed to planting. Since she has achieved something through planting, she knows she can retake the test and succeed. That's why I think the author ended with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with a statement that prompts contemplation as she aims to emphasize the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus. Similar to Saeng, the hibiscus finds itself in a new environment and must adapt to its surroundings. Saeng had recently failed her driving test, leaving her dejected. The concluding sentence makes one realize that if the plant can overcome the harsh environment, Saeng can overcome her driving challenges.
The author includes this as the last paragraph as it can offer hope to Saeng's mother. It can provide hope because they truly need Saeng to pass the test.

It was highly significant that the author concluded the story with that paragraph. It re - established the meaning of the hibiscus and its importance to Saeng. It demonstrated her determination in overcoming the problems of living in a new place. Without this paragraph, readers would have been left speculating about Saeng's future. In some stories, such ambiguity might work, but in this case, it was necessary. When Saeng first saw the hibiscus, she broke down as she couldn't recall her homeland, which is why the hibiscus is so crucial to the story. Restating its importance at the end helped readers understand what might come next, even though the story had ended. It was essential to express this again. The last paragraph states, “This hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The buds symbolize a new beginning for Saeng and a fresh opportunity to overcome her problems. This paragraph was vital, and without it, these events would remain unresolved. As a reader, the meaning of the story becomes much clearer with it.

Including the part about taking the test again when the “hibiscus is budding” brings a sense of closure and conveys a lesson to what would otherwise be an open - ended story. Early in the story, Saeng fails the driver's test. On her way home, she buys a hibiscus. The connection between Saeng and the hibiscus isn't clear to the reader until the last paragraph. The hibiscus represents perseverance and strength. After a harsh winter, the hibiscus can bloom again and continue to thrive. Similarly, after moving from Vietnam and struggling to adapt, Saeng must recover and keep trying. Just as the flower blooms anew, Saeng will take the test a second time and pass. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho ends the story with the statement “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This shows that Saeng overcame her problem and vowed to correct it. The author concludes the story with the line “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to convey Saeng's determination to adapt to new circumstances and her acceptance of change. In “Winter Hibiscus,” the author employs the hibiscus flower to symbolize beauty in unexpected places, adaptation to a new life, and Saeng's home country. The author includes the last line in the story's ending to convey the raids and the sense that although it seems almost over, the protagonist doesn't want it to end. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as the protagonist overcame challenges and wishes to retake the quiz for self - affirmation, not for others. In Minfong Ho's short story “Winter Hibiscus,” a young girl named Saeng remembers her life before moving to @LOCATION1. She yearns for her homeland and the things she loved there. In Minfong Ho's story "Winter Hibiscus", the author includes the phrase “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author aims to end the story with Saeng developing positive views of her new home and future and looking forward to it. In the short story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes with the main character, Saeng, stating that she will take the test “when the snow melts and the geese return.” I believe that the hibiscus and the driver's test are related, much like the blooming of a flower. In Minfong Ho's “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes the story with a paragraph where Saeng vows to take the test again in the spring. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as when Saeng talked to herself, she promised not to give up on obtaining her license. The hibiscus makes her feel at home again. The author concludes the story with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This clearly portrays Saeng, the main character, as a persistent individual. The author concludes the story in a certain way to pique the readers' interest and make them eager to read more.
