The author concludes the story in this manner to signify a new beginning in the spring. Just as flowers blossom and sprout buds during this season, she will transform into a better - version of herself. This is the reason why the author chose this way to end the story.

In my view, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng will retake the test and embark on a fresh start. It also imparts a valuable lesson to readers: if you fail at something initially, don't be afraid to make another attempt. I believe the hibiscus symbolizes Saeng as she failed the test in winter and is dissatisfied with her current circumstances. However, come spring, when the hibiscus has buds, she will have a new chance at the test, much like the flower finding a new environment to thrive in.

The author chose to conclude the story with that paragraph as it allows readers to interpret and draw their own conclusions. It doesn't explicitly state the purpose of the test or whether she passed it; these are left for the readers to determine. Moreover, it leaves readers in suspense about what will happen next. The ending of the story is open - ended, and its meaning can vary from person to person.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because it reveals when she intends to retake the test and make changes in her evolving life. For instance, in the story, she is sad because she failed the test and yearns to go home. If she passes the test in spring, she might decide to make changes and settle down. This is the rationale behind the author's choice to conclude the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng has finally become comfortable in her new "home." After the passage largely reflects on Saeng's old life, this ending signifies her adaptation to the new way of life. For instance, the mention of "in the spring, and the geese return…" indicates that she has grown accustomed to the geese and the natural environment of her new world. Additionally, the author uses this paragraph to convey a sense of release. Saeng had numerous memories from her old life that hindered her from embracing new experiences in her new home. The author's use of this paragraph effectively closes the story, allowing the reader to envision the relaxed scene of the birds flying away, symbolizing Saeng's escape from pain and her integration into the new world.

The final paragraph of the story offers a profound revelation to the reader. Through her mother's understanding and the presence of the hibiscus plant, Saeng is granted new hope. Initially, upon seeing the hibiscus that reminded her of her homeland, she felt hopeless, miserable, and out of place. However, when she returned home and witnessed the plant's roots buried in the ground, a new determination welled up within her. The hibiscus serves as a powerful symbol for Saeng. Just as the plant adapts to survive in cold weather, Saeng endures difficult times in a new country. The roots represent her past; though buried, they are not forgotten. The flower itself symbolizes Saeng's new life in a foreign land. Author Minfong Ho employs personification, attributing human qualities to non - living things, in this story. This creative choice explains the significance of the last paragraph and why it was used in this way.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to showcase Saeng's determination. Moreover, it draws a parallel between the driver's test and the hibiscus plant. The text implies that when everything around her begins to thrive, Saeng will also achieve her goals. She relies on the motivation provided by her surroundings to persevere. Throughout the narrative, Saeng is deeply influenced by her environment. For example, when she enters the greenhouse, it transports her back to her childhood. As described, "It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery.... Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world." This connection emphasizes how her surroundings shape her mindset and drive her forward.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," after failing her test, Saeng finds solace in the hibiscus plant. The plant evokes memories of her home and links her to her past experiences. Despite the initial test failure, Saeng believes that with study and another attempt, she can pass. This parallels the hibiscus plant, which withers in winter but blossoms beautifully in spring. Saeng identifies with the plant's rebirth and feels that she too can start afresh and succeed on the test. This is why the author includes the paragraph where Saeng vows to retake the test when spring arrives and the hibiscus blooms, highlighting her resilience and hope for a new beginning.

In the story, the author concludes with Saeng silently vowing to herself, "when they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author ends the story in this way because Saeng is expressing her belief that the right time will come for her to retake the test. She has faith in herself and is confident that she will pass. This ending encapsulates Saeng's determination and the hope that comes with the renewal of nature in spring, suggesting that she can overcome her previous failure and achieve success.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that in due time, the protagonist will retake the test she failed, believing the hibiscus will assist her in surmounting obstacles. Presumably, she purchased the plant upon failing the test, hoping that as it blossoms, it will indicate when she is ready to attempt the test again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it meaningfully summarizes the events. All that happened to Saeng during her time at the florist can be seen as a form of seeking some form of resolution. Saeng was initially sad because she failed her driving test. In the final paragraph, she vows to retake the test when the hibiscus buds. The hibiscus she bought will start budding in spring when the snow melts. The last paragraph allows Saeng to cope with her winter - time nostalgia. The geese flying south make her sad, but they also inspire her. She tells herself that she will retake the driving test when the geese return, the hibiscus buds, and the snow melts.

In the last paragraph, it's trying to convey what's to come. Once winter ends, spring arrives, and the hibiscus will bloom again, making it feel like home. The return of the geese also prompts her to retake the quiz. For her, it's like a fresh start, and hopefully, she'll pass. Since she loves the hibiscus, its return might help her perform much better. Overall, a new phase is approaching.

I believe the author of “Winter Hibiscus” ended the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because it highlights the significance of the plant and how it will aid her in passing the test. The plant symbolizes that just as it buds and overcomes obstacles to survive, she will overcome the hurdles to pass her driving test. For instance, when the story says “When the snows melt and then geese return,” the author is linking Saeng's struggle to pass the test with the challenges of surviving winter. The quote “Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly disappearing into the distance” implies that she will face her challenge and overcome it. In conclusion, this quote shows the parallel struggles of the flower, Saeng, and the geese to overcome challenges and complete what they've started.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it holds significance. The author implies that when these animals and living beings get their opportunities, so will she. For example, the geese will return, the hibiscus will have its chance to bud, and she will get the chance to take her driver's test. This is evident as Saeng's mother talks about how wonderful the plant will be in spring and says, “But it's strong enough to make it through the cold months.” This shows that the mother is trying to tell her that she will get a second chance, which is why the story ends with that sentence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it describes the seasons, their changes, and their cycles. A new season brings something different. I believe the story is titled "Winter Hibiscus" because winter follows spring. In spring, there are beautiful, fragrant flowers, but when spring ends and winter arrives, the plants die and are no longer the same as before.

In “Winter Hibiscus” by @CAPS1 Ho, Saeng persists and never gives up. The author concludes the story with a short yet profoundly meaningful paragraph. When Saeng says, “…in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again,” she demonstrates a spirit of perseverance, a willingness to embrace new opportunities, and a constant remembrance of her homeland. Ending the story in this inspiring way reinforces the theme, and a great deal can be gleaned from these few words.

The author's choice to end the story with the final paragraph can be attributed to multiple factors. Saeng declares that she will retake her driving test in the spring. In archetypal terms, spring represents a fresh start or a new opportunity. By ending the story with this archetype, it is implied that Saeng will have another chance to succeed in her test and to fully embrace her life in @LOCATION1 and adapt to her new circumstances. When Saeng purchases the hibiscus plant, it evokes memories of her old home in Vietnam and the wonderful moments she spent there. The plant seems to instill hope in her, and the last paragraph of the story makes mention of the hibiscus. This indicates that having the hibiscus around will give her the hope of passing her test and adjusting to @LOCATION1 while still cherishing the memories of her homeland.

The author concludes the story with this statement to convey that when the plants resume growing and the geese return, she will make another attempt. For instance, the plants must regrow their petals, and the geese must rebuild their homes and find food. The author is suggesting that she will retake the test when the geese come back and the plants start to grow again.

The author wrote this paragraph because the character went inside the house to have dinner and won't see the garden again until another day. With winter approaching, she won't be able to play outside until winter passes. As she states, “In the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This quotation explains the author's decision to conclude the story with this paragraph.
The narrator concludes in this way because, upon reflection, it presents a form of solution. Conventionally, a solution is placed at the end, which is why the narrator chose this placement.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng is not giving up and has found a hobby to anticipate. For instance, “the winter hibiscus was in the ground now and Saeng tamped down the soil around it; overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by.” This is the reason the author ends the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with the specific quote to illustrate an understanding of the beauty and marvels of nature. Saeng spent a significant amount of money on a unique flower, the dok faeng - nol. While taking her driver's license test and failing, she discovered this plant. Despite her shame at failing the test, she showed the flower, different from the ones at home, to her mother. Her mother was pleased with the flower and understood her test failure. The mother's comment, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters,” is a figurative way of suggesting there is hope for Saeng to pass her test after further learning. The geese flying away for winter and returning in spring symbolize a fresh start at achieving success.
The author concludes the story in this way because currently, the outside conditions are unfavorable for taking the test. When the weather turns warm and pleasant, they will attempt the test again.

The last statement is truly powerful. Despite failing her driver's test, Saeng realizes she must remain strong and patient. As the geese return and the snow melts, she will be determined to retake the test and pass. Saeng bought the hibiscus to evoke a sense of being back in Vietnam, filling the void in her heart for her homeland. When she says, “I paid nineteen dollars for it,” it shows her disappointment at failing the test and the shock of the flower's high cost in the United States compared to its free availability in Vietnam. Since the hibiscus is a tropical flower, its blooming in spring represents her readiness to retake the test.

The author concludes the story in this way as it implies that if the plant revives and blossoms, the protagonist will retake the test and strive to pass. She is aware that passing the test will be arduous, yet she believes she can succeed, just as she is certain that the plant will endure the winter and bloom in spring. This comparison gives her the confidence that if the plant can overcome the harsh winter, she can pass the test. Hence, this is the reason the author ended the story thus.

In my view, the author concludes the story by stating that the character will retake the driver's test. This is because not only will she attempt the test again, but she will also feel more at ease in her life. The driver's test is not the core issue; rather, it is the difficulty of adapting to the new environment that causes Saeng great distress. For instance, in the text, Saeng has thoughts like “A wave of loss so deep and strong stung Saeng’s eyes now and swept over her” and “in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.” This shows that Saeng is struggling to readjust to her new life, is reminded of her past in her old home, and cries due to its loss. I believe that failing the driver's test was the final straw that made her cry under the stress. When she said “and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again,” it indicates that she will overcome all these challenges and move forward.

It was a wise choice for the author to conclude the story with this paragraph. Saeng has a deep affection for the hibiscus. When spring arrives and the hibiscus blooms, it will be the ideal time for her to retake the driving test after her previous failure. This timing is likely to boost her confidence for the test. In conclusion, this is the reason why the author ended the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story in this manner because the character implies that she will grow with the changing seasons. She is in a new country and has just failed her driver's test, feeling dejected. However, the hibiscus reminds her of her homeland. In the story, the mother says “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake; it’s strong enough to make it through the winter.” Saeng can relate to this because if the flower can survive the winter, she can adapt to life in a new country.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ends the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author concludes the story with this paragraph because at the start, Saeng bought a hibiscus plant as it reminded her of her hometown. As the text states, “Plants that she had not realized that she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.” So she purchased it. Due to bad weather, Saeng needed to get the plant and plant it in the garden in time but failed. This is why she says “I will take that test again.” She will retake the test in spring when the hibiscus blooms once more. This is the reason the author ended the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the paragraph in this way as it demonstrates that she is not going to give up. This can be inferred from her silent vow to herself to retake the test in spring. Additionally, certain elements in the text seem to imply a sense of perseverance. In conclusion, this is the reason why the author concludes the paragraph like this.

The story “Winter Hibiscus” is penned by Minfong Ho. The author concludes the story with the excerpt, “When they come back, ‘Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.’” The purpose of this ending is to allow Saeng time to adjust. Since all of this is new to her, she just needs a bit of comfort. The use of “Almost familiar to her now. Like geese” is figurative language as the geese remind her of herself. In conclusion, this ending effectively portrays Saeng's state of mind and her plans for the future.

It is almost spring, just as he said. The snow is melting, the geese are returning, and the hibiscus is budding. The grass is growing, the trees are budding, and the birds are singing. This all indicates the arrival of a new and vibrant season, full of life and hope.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes with an interesting paragraph: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author ends the story this way because Saeng is out of her comfort zone. She has moved to a new country and misses things like the flowers and the hibiscus. So, she decides to wait until she feels at home and comfortable again to retake the test. As the text states, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now,” showing that she is realizing it's not so bad and is getting used to the new environment. In conclusion, this ending reflects Saeng's adaptation process and her determination to face the test when the time is right.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This ending is crafted to make the audience think and adds a touch of dramatic effect to the story. By leaving Saeng's future test - taking in the context of the changing seasons, it creates a sense of anticipation and depth. In conclusion, this ending successfully engages the audience and enriches the story.

The author concludes the story in this manner to demonstrate that the protagonist will be fine and retain her determination. Her way of referring to future times indicates her confidence in making it until spring. The way she talks about the test showcases her resolve. The use of the word “vowed” suggests that she will fulfill her statement.
The author concluded the story with this sentence to convey that she prefers nature over school.
The author concludes this story with this paragraph as the flower is a recurring element throughout the narrative. The author mentions that when the hibiscus is budding, she will take the test again.

The author concludes this story with this paragraph as she is informing the readers about events that will occur beyond the scope of the story we are reading. It implies that when the snow melts, she will start anew and reconstruct the greenhouse.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story the way she does to illustrate determination. I also think it symbolizes adaptation. Just as the season changes, Saeng will adapt and take the test again. Everything will soon return to normal and adjust, just as she will. As the text states, everything is “almost familiar to her now”.

The author concludes the story with this ending as it offers hope, akin to a happy ending for a sad tale. It represents the author's final thought for the story and serves as an appropriate conclusion.
The author concludes this paragraph in the story because at this point, the character starts growing plants again, signifying her desire to have a fresh start.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as it indicates that Saeng will make another attempt once spring arrives. For instance, the statement “I failed the test” (Ho) shows that Saeng indeed failed the test, yet she got her mother a hibiscus to plant in the garden. Her mother, feeling remorseful about Saeng's failure, cooks food for her to comfort her and help her move past the set - back. This is significant as it gives Saeng a sense of comfort and relief, knowing she can take the test again with confidence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph due to several reasons. Saeng makes a silent vow to herself, which shows that she has calmed down and has adapted well to her new country. When she observes the snow melting and the geese returning, she declares that she will retake the test. This indicates that she is no longer overly troubled by the test failure. She realizes she has the opportunity to take it again and do better. Her perspective on her problem has changed, and she views her new country with a fresh outlook. All aspects of her life are improving, which explains why the author ends the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to illustrate that she will embark on a new attempt with a fresh start. When Saeng sees the flower, the clerk tells her it is a hibiscus. The hibiscus evokes memories of her childhood. She then takes it home and shows it to her mother, who responds with a “You what?” upon hearing the price. The hibiscus, being something of significance, instills more hope in her. By stating that she will start anew once the flower has bloomed and the geese have returned, she implies that she will make a fresh and renewed effort.

The author concludes the story with the given paragraph to illustrate Saeng's determination in the face of sadness. Although she misses Vietnam, she intends to retake the test next year. The author's word - choice in the concluding paragraph evokes a sense of hope and anticipation. In the story, Saeng is disappointed in herself for failing the test, but purchasing the plant aids her as it reminds her of home. The final paragraph effectively conveys Saeng's persistence and the hopeful tone of the story.

The author concluded the story with that specific paragraph because it seemed to be a crucial thought for "Saeng" and was essentially the main subject of the story. Additionally, the author might have ended the story with that paragraph as it was Saeng's last memory of her previous lifestyle before moving to their current place of living.

The author concludes the story with the line “In the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” because Saeng failed the test. She spent her money on a Big Mac and didn't have enough to buy the type of flower her mother had sent for. Since she failed, she wants to retake the test to make her mother happy.

I think the author ended the story with that sentence because it offers a sense of uplift after a sad narrative. Saeng missed her homeland, was sad about her driving - test failure, found solace in the flowers, and really liked the plant. The last sentence serves as a comfort zone, making the reader feel a bit more at ease.

The author concludes the story with the final lines to establish a hopeful tone that forms a theme. Final lines have a significant impact on readers as they are the last thing read. In this story, when Saeng refers to “when the snow melts”, the snow symbolizes the sorrow she experiences due to leaving home. At one point, “Saeng broke down and wept”. Spring is a time of archetypal rebirth, so when “the snow will melt”, her sorrow will fade away, creating a tone of hope for future happiness. Next, when Saeng mentions the hibiscus budding, the hibiscus represents a comforting link to her old country. She calls the plant “yet another old friend”. If the hibiscus blooms, her new life will thrive as she will feel secure. This creates a tone of hope for future comfort. The times she speaks of are followed by a promise to retake the test despite her first - time failure. The author uses the theme of hope to show that we can overcome difficulties. Saeng shows optimism towards spring and is willing to face challenges, thus imparting a life lesson of courage.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the given paragraph to emphasize the significance of the Winter Hibiscus. In the narrative, Saeng relocates from Vietnam and experiences intense homesickness. She fails her driver's test and is deeply upset. Upon seeing the familiar plant, she is transported back to her home in Vietnam. The Winter Hibiscus evokes fond memories of her grandmother and simple things like her fine - toothed buffalo - horn comb and the hibiscus hedge that left soft red petals in her well water. The text states that “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral,” highlighting the plant's importance to her. By ending the story with this paragraph, the author demonstrates that the winter hibiscus offers comfort to Saeng and will likely inspire her to perform better on her next driver's test.

After reading “Winter Hibiscus,” it's evident that Saeng is a determined individual with an affinity for nature. She is also resolute in her goal to pass the driving test. The author concludes the story with the specific paragraph because at the start of the tale, Saeng fails her driving test. She then walks home and, during her walk, encounters a familiar plant that transports her to her childhood. Had she not failed the test, she wouldn't have walked home and come across the plant. The author includes this to ensure the readers don't forget the reason for her walking home, as it was a pivotal event in the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that Saeng will have another opportunity next spring. The author suggests that Saeng will associate with the blooms of the hibiscus plant and attempt the driving test again. By doing so, the author creates a cliff - hanger, indicating that there is more to Saeng's life yet to unfold. In the story, Saeng struggles to adapt to change. Her mother tries to cheer her up, but just as winter arrives, Saeng must wait until next spring to retake the driver's test. This ending shows that there is hope and a new chance for Saeng in the future.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, … then I will take the test again” because Saeng, like the hibiscus, needs time to grow. Saeng did not perform well on a test but declares that she will try again after the snow melts and spring arrives. After moving, Saeng feels lonely and longs to return home. However, in her heart, she believes that given time, she can persevere. The hibiscus reminds Saeng of the flowers in her home country, helping her realize that she must let go of the past and embrace the present. This ending shows Saeng's growth and her ability to face the future with hope.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it portrays Saeng as mature and confident. She understands that she can take the test again. When the text says “Saeng vowed silently to herself,” it implies that she has reflected on everything and is on the verge of a fresh start. This ending shows Saeng's resilience and her positive outlook towards the future, suggesting that she will learn from her experience and move forward with determination.

The author concludes the story with a sentence regarding retaking the test when the geese return and the hibiscus begins to bud, as each symbolizes something else. The geese symbolize change, as they alter their environment during winter, similar to how Saeng changes hers by going to the plant place. The hibiscus evokes a sense of home for her, as there are comparable plants at her residence. The budding hibiscus represents a new life, just as Saeng has to start anew in a new home. Overall, the author's concluding sentence is used to compare Saeng's life to that of the geese and the hibiscus.

Saeng was elated as the snow started to melt because she eagerly anticipated spring's return. She looked forward to seeing the animals frolic around her garden and the majestic geese flying in after their long hibernation. Saeng was excited to witness everything come back to life, confident that this time she would pass the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph due to Saeng's anticipation for winter to end. Once winter is over, Saeng will retake the test and plant flowers. Saeng has a deep affection for the hibiscus and hopes it won't perish during winter. This conclusion ties together Saeng's eagerness for a new season and her connection to the flower.

The author concluded the story with this paragraph to illustrate how the flower provided strength to the little girl. The girl found herself in a new place, far from home where there were numerous beautiful flowers she adored. The absence of these flowers in the new location made her feel down and upset. She missed her home deeply and was in pain, with the flowers being the only source of mild comfort. For example, when the girl said, “It’s - it's not a real one...I mean, not like the kind we had at...”, she stopped, too distraught to say “home”. Although the flower she currently has is not real, when the real one blooms in spring, it will comfort her and give her the confidence to retake the test.

The author's conclusion reveals her feelings. The statement “when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” indicates that she has transformed into a new person. Taking the test implies change and a readiness to embrace new challenges. For her, the test represents stepping into the unknown. This is the message I gleaned from the conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that Saeng has hope and that hope still exists. The ending paragraph allows readers to envision their own ending for Saeng. I prefer to picture Saeng having a large garden beside her and successfully passing the test.

In my view, the author chose to conclude the story with this paragraph for multiple reasons. The final paragraph consolidates and integrates all the concluding ideas. It indicates that in spring, when nature awakens, Saeng will gather the strength to retake the test. The central ideas in the last paragraph illustrate how Saeng and her mother have adapted, and that spring ushers in new beginnings and possibilities. As stated in the text, “I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.” This implies that despite the differences from Saeng's home, they will adapt and survive in their own way.

The author concludes the story in this manner as it demonstrates that Saeng needs to recover from the disappointment of failing the test before attempting it again. Saeng is aware that she can heal. She realizes that she has grown accustomed to her new surroundings, and that aspects of her new land, such as the sound of geese, have become “familiar to her.” As the narrator states, “...she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become… almost familiar to her now.” Initially, things in Saeng's new home seemed strange, but she has healed and adjusted. Saeng has also overcome the pain of leaving her native Vietnam. Although she was heart - broken to leave, as described by “A work so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her,” she has healed. Saeng remembers the flowers from Vietnam as “old friends,” indicating that recalling them no longer causes pain. Once Saeng recovers from failing her driving test, just as she adapted to moving from Vietnam to the United States, she can retake the test without the burden of pain.

I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it shows that the character, Saeng, will adapt to her new home and remain resilient. When Saeng's mother says, “Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus,” I think she is also referring to Saeng. It's as if she's suggesting that the move has affected Saeng, but she will be strong and endure the change. Similar to someone who fails a test, Saeng will study harder and strive to pass it the next time. Saeng won't give up and will persevere. She knows that adjusting to life's changes is difficult, but with a bit of courage and hard work, it will be manageable. If she believes in herself, she will be able to settle into this new place.

When they return, Saeng silently vows to herself that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese come back, and the winter hibiscus begins to bud, she will retake the test. There are several reasons for this. Winter with its snow destroys her garden. So, she longs for spring to start growing plants in her garden again. She has to take a test on the plants she grows to ensure they are suitable for consumption. That's why I think the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” is significant.

In Minfong Ho's story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concluded the narrative with an engaging paragraph: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again” (@NUM1). This indicates that the girl is acclimating to her new country and anticipates performing better in the spring. The author ended the story with this paragraph as it demonstrates that the girl has successfully adapted to her new homeland and is resolved to grow stronger over time. She implies that when the hibiscus blossoms again, she will be prepared to retake the test and avoid failure.

The budding of the hibiscus signifies that the flower is in the process of growth. The hibiscus is a flower renowned for its vivid and bright colors, and in nature, few other flowers can rival its beauty. The reason other flowers cannot outshine it is that the hibiscus holds significant symbolic value and is one of the most naturally - occurring and distinctive flowers. In essence, its unique charm and symbolism set it apart from other floral species.

The author chose to conclude the story with that particular paragraph because it aligned with the envisioned ending of the narrative. The author intended to end the story with the character engaged in self - dialogue, which provided a fitting and intimate way to close the tale, allowing the reader to gain a final insight into the character's thoughts.

When people relocate, they are often required to adapt to different cultures. They can achieve this through various means, such as making new friends and getting accustomed to the local environment. Nevertheless, while adjusting to a new place, it is important to retain memories of one's former home. This concept is exemplified in the ending paragraph of Minfong Ho's “Winter Hibiscus.” In the story, a teenage girl named Saeng moves from Vietnam to @LOCATION2. While visiting a plant store, she has numerous recollections of her past home. She purchases a plant that is common in Vietnam and plants it in her garden. The last paragraph of the story states, “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that driving test again.” This showcases Saeng's aspiration to integrate into the new culture by taking the driving test, while also remembering her past through the hibiscus. The final paragraph effectively encapsulates Saeng's feelings for her old country and her determination to succeed in the new one.

She made a promise to herself that when spring returns, she will retake the driver's test. This self - commitment shows her determination and eagerness to overcome the previous setback and achieve success in obtaining her driver's license. By tying her goal to the arrival of spring, a season often associated with new beginnings and growth, she infuses her promise with a sense of hope and renewal.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to demonstrate her determination. When Saeng states, “...when the snows melt and the geese return and his hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” she is drawing a parallel between the geese's determination to fly back and the hibiscus's determination to bud anew. She reasons that if they can show such determination, she too should have the resolve and confidence to retake the test. Saeng had previously admitted, “I - I failed the test,” and it seemed that this driving test failure made her fear failure in the new country. However, after witnessing the geese and hibiscus persevere through harsh conditions, she became determined to attempt the test once more.

The author ends the story with that paragraph to convey that she has already taken the test, and since it is currently winter, she will retake it when all the flowers and plants revive and start anew. Saeng wishes to retake the test to prove to her mother that she can pass. To this end, she spent nineteen dollars on a plant called “dorl Faeng - noi” to avoid disappointing her mother. Nevertheless, her mother was disappointed that she spent so much money on a plant.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it reveals that seeing things from her homeland and daily life brings her comfort in her actions. The author appears to rely on elements from her native land to make the best of situations and recall pleasant memories of her earlier life. I find that whenever I aim to do well, thinking about the things that hold great significance for me makes me happy and motivated to perform well. The author is wise to want to see those things before retaking her test. If she sees her plant thriving and is reminded of the geese, it will likely bring her good luck.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng has gained a new sense of hope from her memories and the now - familiar aspects of her new home. The combination of failing the driver's test and being away from her original home made Saeng feel a profound sense of loss. In the flower shop, “aware of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her.” Throughout the rest of the story, Saeng remains down, leaving the reader uncertain about her well - being. However, her recovery begins with the presence of familiar things. “The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered,” “The winter hibiscus was in the ground now,” and “overhead a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and – yes – familiar to Saeng now.” The realization that the geese are familiar to her leads to new insights and a wave of hope. She realizes that she is becoming accustomed to many things in her new home that initially seemed strange. This is what the final paragraph conveys to the reader, summarizing Saeng's new hope that she will not only survive but thrive in her new home.

In my view, the author concludes the story with this statement as it shows that, for her, the hibiscus symbolizes overcoming obstacles. When she says, “...and the geese return and this is budding, I will take that test again” (Ho @NUM1), it indicates that despite failing the test this time, she will retake it when the hibiscus grows. This shows her determination to overcome obstacles. Additionally, the hibiscus “gives her strength from her old country,” which means it will help her overcome the test by providing comfort and strength. Thus, the author uses this statement to end the story, highlighting the hibiscus's symbolic role in Saeng's journey of overcoming challenges.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph as it indicates that Saeng is confident and willing to return and take the test. Saeng has a positive self - perception and is eager to undertake this task.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng was engaged in a test. In the story, there are quotes to support this, such as “I - I failed the test,” Saeng said, which reveals that she was taking a gardening test. Another reason for the author to end the story with this paragraph is that the story revolved around spring, gardening, and the associated way of life. The paragraph discusses spring and flowers. The daughter and mother sustain themselves by planting vegetables and fruits.

The last paragraph of “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho is crucial to the story. It provides a definite ending, allowing the reader to clearly envision what will occur in the future. This paragraph serves as a highly significant conclusion as it represents symbols within the story. The author conveys that the hibiscus holds importance for the character. Alongside the hibiscus, the geese and the melting snow symbolize a fresh start and a new beginning. These symbols are vital as they offer the character an opportunity to start afresh, and she recognizes this in the winter hibiscus.

Saeng was extremely distraught upon learning that she had not passed the test. To her, it was a significant let - down or disappointment. This situation showcases Saeng's ambition and determination, as she is clearly driven to pass this test.

The author concludes the story with the part “when they come back …” to illustrate how Saeng has transformed throughout the story's plot. At the beginning, she described her new home as “walking into another world.” As a teenager, she had to relocate from Vietnam, where traditions differ greatly from those in the United States. However, there is one common plant, the winter Hibiscus. This plant bridges her past life and home with her current one. Adapting to the move was challenging, but the plant brought familiar scents and a “familiar fragrance” that “filled her lungs.” It was even difficult for Saeng to say “at home” without crying. Once the winter Hibiscus was planted, it changed Saeng, and she realized she needed to appreciate what she had. In conclusion, the author ended the story with that paragraph because it demonstrated how the plant mirrored Saeng and how her outlook on life had changed.

In my view, the author concludes the story with this phrase to illustrate how Saeng is adapting to her new home while still cherishing her old one. The essence of the sentence is that Saeng will retake the test in spring, which demonstrates her perseverance. Moreover, the sentence shows Saeng's growing familiarity with her new land. When she says, “when the snows melt and the geese return,” it is significant as the geese and snow are part of her new home, and she now accepts them. However, when Saeng also says, “when this hibiscus is budding,” it reveals that she is still thinking of her old home, as the plant is her link to the memories of Vietnam. Therefore, I believe the author uses this statement to conclude the story to show how Saeng is growing up and coping with the changes in her life.

I believe that what the author is trying to convey is that during winter, the hibiscus struggles against the cold. While most plants simply perish, the hibiscus confronts the cold head - on. This showcases the hibiscus's resilience in the face of harsh winter conditions, highlighting its unique ability to endure rather than succumb to the elements.

I think the author includes this part to avoid leaving the audience in suspense about what would happen next. The quote “I will take the test again” indicates that although Saeng may have failed the test related to the plant, she will never give up and will try again in spring. I feel that the author added this to help readers better understand the experience of leaving one's homeland to come to an unfamiliar place, just like the flower situation in the story. When Saeng thought about the plants and their scents, it brought back old feelings about her homeland and her close relationship with her grandmother. She was accustomed to seeing plants growing freely, not confined in pots. Witnessing this made Saeng break down and cry. In conclusion, I believe the author added the final paragraph to aid understanding and to show that although Saeng is in a new place with a new culture, she will never stop trying until she passes the test.

I firmly believe that the author of “Winter Hibiscus” deliberately included the last paragraph, and in my opinion, the story is much better with it. In the last paragraph, the line “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” is truly impactful. When the author describes these natural phenomena, it symbolizes rebirth, a fresh start, and a new chance, which is exactly what Saeng needs for her driver's license test. The author effectively uses these symbols to convey hope for the girl to overcome her difficult time. Finally, the last paragraph gives the story a sense of completeness and closure, making it a well - rounded and finished piece.

I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph because it is a valuable learning story from which readers can gain insights. The author does this to help readers better understand the story. The statement “Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam” provides background information on what happened right before the story began, enabling readers to have a clearer understanding. To me, it wraps up the story neatly. That's why I believe the author chose to end the story with this paragraph.

I believe the author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story in this way because Saeng agrees to retake the test. She intends to take the test when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud, that is, when spring arrives, she will be prepared for the test. In the story, Saeng states, “It’s the flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.” I think Saeng uses this as a guiding principle since she has just moved from Vietnam. She plans to persevere and uses the plant as a symbol. She will attempt to obtain her driver's license again at the start of spring, showing her determination to overcome the set - back.

The author included the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” as it symbolizes her mother's renewal, awakening, and restoration. Saeng expressed her intention to retake the driving test when this occurs. She was deeply saddened by her failure, saying “I – I failed the test,” and seemed both embarrassed and sad. The last paragraph effectively depicts Saeng's plan. She will adopt an optimistic outlook, restore herself, and return to pass the test, demonstrating her resilience in the face of disappointment.

As the narrator, I appreciate this paragraph in the story. The hibiscus is a valuable plant, and having a garden is a personal choice, much like how Saeng's mother chose to grow hot peppers. A garden is a means to experience diversity, such as the various types of foods one can plant and the different plants in the world, including roses, lilies, and other similar ones. It showcases the beauty and variety that nature offers and the personal decisions we make in interacting with it.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as Saeng is attempting to overcome an obstacle. Failing the driver's test was a setback for her, so she decides to take it again. She uses the hibiscus as motivation because the winter for the hibiscus represents the process of overcoming difficulties. Just as the hibiscus endures the cold months, Saeng will persevere through her challenges and try to succeed in obtaining her driver's license, highlighting the theme of resilience in the story.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it reveals the significance of the test to Saeng. It shows that she genuinely cares about passing the test. By demonstrating her concern, she is motivated to take the test again. This conclusion emphasizes her determination and the emotional investment she has in achieving this goal, making the story more impactful and showing her growth in the face of a challenge.

She concludes the story with that paragraph to convey that she feels most at ease during spring. Additionally, she expresses her eagerness for the geese and hibiscus to start budding as it is her favorite time of the year.

Saeng is uncomfortable in her new surroundings and has not adapted to the changes from her previous location. She spots a hibiscus and decides to purchase it as it reminds her of her home in @LOCATION2. When she brings it home, her mother is initially shocked by the price Saeng paid but becomes more understanding when she realizes Saeng misses @LOCATION2. Saeng says she will retake her test in the spring, implying that she will change her attitude about living in @LOCATION1.
I believe the author concludes the story in that way because they are referring to the return of the geese.

The author reaches this conclusion to demonstrate that Saeng was not giving up. Saeng moved to a place she disliked and knew no one. The author aims to convey that no matter the circumstances, one should not give up and should have faith. By the end, Saeng has faith in herself to pass the test next time. She may have realized that being in an undesired place does not mean one cannot move forward.

The author concludes the story in this manner to convey to the reader that one should not quit upon failure. When Saeng stated that she would return to take the test again in spring, it shows her determination not to quit and her belief that life will continue. This is why I think the author chose this conclusion for the story.

In my view, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that she is unwilling to abandon the fight against homesickness. When she first purchased that plant, it evoked memories of her former home, revealing the depth of her longing. By stating that she will take the test again, it demonstrates that she refuses to let this setback defeat her in her new home and new life.

The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to demonstrate that Saeng possesses the ability to overcome obstacles. Saeng perceives herself as a failure. Her hibiscus symbolizes the courage to surmount the obstacle of her failed driving test. The geese represent survival and the determination to never give up, to consistently strive for success. In essence, the author uses these elements to convey Saeng's potential for growth and resilience.

I believe the author concludes the story in this way because the girl in the narrative is akin to the flower. Just as the flower will bloom, Saeng will retake the test, both getting a new beginning. Ending the story like this leaves the reader with a positive feeling. It's a brief yet meaningful conclusion. The line “...and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” is truly inspiring, making one want to start anew just like Saeng.

The author concludes the story with “When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” for multiple valid reasons. Firstly, it shows that she will continue to move forward and adapt to her new life in Canada. She intends to change her lifestyle and integrate into the new culture. Additionally, she has to relive the memory of her grandmother and wishes to handle it more effectively, as seen in “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eye now swept over her.” The author emphasizes that the story is not over, suggesting there is more growth and development in store for the character.

There are numerous reasons the narrator might have ended the story with this paragraph. Firstly, since it is the start of winter, the hibiscus will not return until spring. Moreover, as it is the end of the story, it serves as an excellent way to conclude, aligning with the end - cycle of the hibiscus. The last paragraph also succinctly summarizes the story. Its brevity and charm make it a great ending. It stands out as unique because most story endings are not centered around nature. In conclusion, there are many valid reasons for the narrator's choice to end the story with this paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate how individuals can regain their determination. At the start of the story, Saeng is disheartened after failing her driving test. Upon seeing the Hibiscus, she is inundated with memories of the past and begins to weep. Her mother's kindness enables Saeng to draw strength from the flower, which, as her mother remarks, is "strong enough to make it through the cold months here." Anticipating that the Hibiscus will bud in the spring, Saeng renews her resolve to pass the test.

The author concludes with this response as they aim to convey that Saeng will repeat her actions, but this time she will be more helpful in the garden for her mother. She will also try harder with her schoolwork and focus less on gardening.

In my opinion, Saeng's personality in this story showcases determination and confidence. I believe she feels capable of handling more experienced tasks related to different plants. This is, in my view, a perfect hobby experience for someone who loves plants. I feel that by @MONTH1, Saeng has accomplished her goals of planting. I think she @MONTH1 desires to pursue a career in gardening. When she said that when the plants come back, she would take the test again, I think she means she is willing to explore more plants. I believe she @MONTH1 gained this planting experience from her mother. To me, this @MONTH1 has been a family tradition. Saeng will likely have kids and teach them about different types of flowers.

The author ended the story with the paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng is looking forward to her life with a positive outlook. It indicates that she will no longer be depressed by the changes in her life. The hibiscus serves as a plot device in this story. When changes occur to the hibiscus, corresponding changes take place in the story. Initially, Saeng is without the hibiscus and feels hopeless. When she sees it, she recalls her past and is saddened. Once she plants it, the situation starts to improve. When the last paragraph states, "when they come back... and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," it shows that Saeng is viewing her future positively. With this positive change, the hibiscus is now beginning to bloom. The author concludes the story symbolically, which helps to convey the story's themes.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “Saeng vowed silently to herself” because Saeng wants to act in the proper time and season. During the “winter season,” the land or soil was so cold that plants could not grow properly. “Hibiscus costs nineteen dollars,” and Saeng failed the test. “There was a frail, wiry beauty to her mother that touched Saeng deeply”; her mother shines when working with plants. All these descriptions from the past lead Saeng to want to make corrections, shine like her mother, and pass the test.

At the conclusion of the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng states, “when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Here, she is referring to her driver's test. She decides to retake the test as she is reminded that her family didn't give up; they moved to @LOCATION1 for a fresh start. The “plant she had forgotten drew her back to her childhood world.” After failing the test, seeing these flowers makes her recall that she has never given up before, so she won't do so now.

The author aims to convey a sense of hope for Saeng in her new country. After noting her test failure, presumably a citizenship test, the author concludes the story in a way that reassures the reader. It is evident that this test was significant as Saeng couldn't even look her mother in the eye, which was likely the reason she bought the flower for her mother. The ending reassures the reader, eliminating any concerns about Saeng's future.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that Saeng will attempt to find the flower to evoke memories of her old home. It shows that the flower will return and survive, even if it is not from the place she originally desired. In the story, Saeng says, “I failed the test,” indicating that the hibiscus she bought was not what she expected. In the last paragraph, she states that she will take the test again, expressing her intention to find a winter hibiscus like the ones in her homeland. She hopes the flowers will survive and that she will find a similar one. As the last paragraph reads, “Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” suggesting she hopes and prays to find a flower like those from her old homeland.
The author ended the story quickly, which is why the story concludes with this particular part. The hasty ending was likely a choice to wrap up the narrative promptly.

When spring arrives and the snow melts, she plans to plant new seeds. The author concludes the story this way because she didn't perform well on the test the first time. However, next year, she will work with her plants and then retake the test to pass it. The author includes this in the conclusion to prevent readers from thinking that she only worries about the plants. Instead, it shows that she is using her work with the plants as a way to prepare herself for the test and move forward.

The story "Winter Hibiscus" revolves around a girl named Saeng, along with her mother and grandmother. Flowers hold great beauty for them, and they spend the whole day planting, picking, and presumably doing other flower - related activities. At one point, Saeng did not dare to look her mother in the eye.

I believe the author concludes the story with that saying because it demonstrates the protagonist's self - confidence. Despite failing the test, she knows she can take it again and pass. Initially, she was upset about the failure. However, after talking with her mother, she felt better and more confident to retake the test, knowing she could succeed. That's why I think the author chose to end the story with that particular saying.

In my opinion, this paragraph implies that when winter ends and the geese return from the south, and her favorite plant from her old country reappears, she will attempt what she previously tried. This time, though, she will do so with greater confidence. That's what I understand this paragraph to mean.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it effectively sums up the plot and resolves the conflict of Saeng failing her driver's test. When Saeng declared, "… I will take that test again," it clearly showed her determination to pass the test and try once more. Since the conflict has been resolved, introducing a new conflict would be necessary to continue the story. So, the author decides to end it. The excerpt from the last paragraph also draws a parallel between Saeng's difficulties in getting her driver's license and the hardships faced by geese. Just like the geese, Saeng will face hardships again but is willing to confront them.

In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the author ends the story in a well - crafted manner. The final paragraph is used to show that Saeng will not be disheartened, even though she is far from home. At the start of the story, she was in a downward spiral after failing a test, and the hibiscus made her feel nostalgic. When she got home, her mother greeted her with kind words and prepared food without peppers and bitter melons, acting like an anti - depressant. This made Saeng see the positive aspects of life, giving her the confidence not to give up and to believe she will pass the test.

In the story, Saeng fails her driving test. While walking home, she spots a familiar plant. She then visits a florist and learns that the plant is a hibiscus. With the little money she has, she purchases the plant as it reminds her of her homeland, childhood, and the grandmother she left behind, forging a connection with it. Additionally, she observes geese flying south for the winter and says, “When they come back,” referring to when the geese fly north in the spring. She also mentions “when the snow melts,” indicating the arrival of warmer weather and the start of spring, and “when this hibiscus is budding,” meaning when spring arrives and the plant begins to bloom. At that time, she will “take that test again,” vowing to retake the failed driving test in spring. She gives herself the winter to practice and prepare for the test, determined to pass it when spring comes.

She said this to demonstrate the determination required to succeed, regardless of how many times one fails. One must get back up and try again. By doing so, she also showcases her courage, as it takes great strength for someone to face failure and then persevere. She refuses to accept failure and aims to redeem herself, which is why she declares she will try again. This is the reason she ended the story in that manner.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph so that readers will know what the protagonist plans to do next spring. This may also inspire them to envision a continuation of the story, as they are informed that she will take the test in the spring.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with that paragraph because when winter arrives, the hibiscus plant she loves will disappear. The flower brought her good luck, so she says, “When the snow melts in the spring, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The flower holds great significance for her. She remarks, “That rich, sweet scent that was familiar too,” comparing the flower's smell to that of her grandmother's shell, finding them to be the same.
The author concludes the story in this way because the protagonist intends to return and repeat the same actions the following year.
The author concludes the story in this way because the protagonist wants to retake the test. Her motivation is to pass the test for her mother, so she brings home a flower to apologize to her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as the events in the story are cyclical, similar to the changing seasons where one cannot plant or grow in winter. For instance, the protagonist remarks that the plants are unlike her home, yet she must adapt to being away from home and adjust to her new environment. If she fails to do so, she will remain unhappy, constantly dwelling on her origins.

In my opinion, the author concludes the response by stating that when spring arrives and the hibiscus begins to bud, the girl will retake the test. This is because she likely feels a sense of hope and faith. The girl has recently moved away from home and is extremely lonely and depressed as she longs to return. The sight of the plant evokes nostalgia and offers her a sense of comfort, as if she were back home. When she says, “In the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it is evident that her failure on the test has upset her, and the plant provides the comfort and confidence she needs to believe she will pass in the spring.
When they return, Saeng silently vows to herself that in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese come back, and the hibiscus starts to bud, she will take that test again.

In “@CAPS1 Hibiscus” by @PERSON1, the author selects the last paragraph as it aligns with the tone, hope, and representation of the essay. The story has a depressing mood as the protagonist fails the driver's test and is deeply upset. When she sees the winter hibiscus, memories of her native country flood back. “And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept,” indicating her intense longing for Vietnam. The onset of winter makes her feel that all hope is lost. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now,” showing that the same old routine year after year brings no new hope. The plant's representation deeply affects her. “She found that she was still too shaky to say the word at home, lest she burst into tears again,” highlighting that home for her is in Vietnam, not the United States. The winter hibiscus triggers a flood of emotions related to her past. The last paragraph reflects how she will try again when hope returns in spring. The tone, hope, and representation all support the choice of the last paragraph, which is why it fits so well.

This was an extremely captivating story that vividly depicted all the hardships the young girl endured. The author concluded it in a highly engaging manner. When the story ended, I couldn't help but think about how beautifully it concluded. I believe the author did an outstanding job. She managed to portray all the difficulties Saeng faced, likening them to a harsh winter. Then, as the author stated, “as the snow melts away…”, I think this symbolizes that even though Saeng's problems seem endless and severe, one day they will vanish, and things will become beautiful again, much like a flower budding in spring. Moreover, she did a great job because throughout the story, I could deeply feel Saeng's pain. Thanks to her use of descriptive words such as “exploding”, “shock”, “intense” and others to describe the suddenness of events, I felt as if I was right there with Saeng. When the story ended, it was as if the author was showing us Saeng's hope for a better future, despite the fact that things were not the same as back home.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” because Saeng believes that when the hibiscus blooms, she too can bloom by passing the test. Saeng relates herself to the hibiscus. Her mother tells her “Its flower isn't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through here, this winter hibiscus.”, trying to convey that Saeng can also be strong and make it through the tough times. When Saeng “like the geese she lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance”, she realizes that she should be proud of herself and that there will be other chances. She should not always doubt herself and should not be afraid to try again. In conclusion, through these elements, the story encourages a positive and resilient attitude.

The author concludes the story with a particular paragraph to signify that the protagonist will return after winter to care for a plant. By placing this in the ending paragraph, the author conveys the protagonist's deep affection for the plant. The plant serves as a powerful reminder of her hometown, which is the reason she takes such meticulous care of it. In this way, the plant becomes a tangible link to her past and a source of comfort in her new surroundings. Ultimately, the act of caring for the plant is a way for her to carry a piece of home with her.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph about the geese as it illustrates that Saeng, similar to the geese, will adapt to her new environment. Just as the geese do what is necessary to survive, Saeng will also take the necessary steps to thrive. She is determined to take the test again and will not give up. The paragraph reflects her desire to adapt to the new country. For instance, the narration mentions “… she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes”, which shows that Saeng is not accustomed to being in the new country and dislikes it. However, as demonstrated in the closing paragraph, she will get used to it and make her best efforts. Additionally, the narration states “…she admitted to herself, she much preferred it to a Big Mac”, proving that even though Saeng may not like certain things at times, she is willing to try them to adjust to the new country. Moreover, “…she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become familiar to her now” indicates that Saeng is increasingly getting used to her surroundings, just as the geese adapt. This is why the author ended the story with the paragraph about the geese.

I firmly believe that the author wrote the conclusion paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng is looking forward to a more promising future. Saeng hopes to see the geese once again as they remind her of her homeland, and she also wants to pass the driving test. In this story, I perceive Saeng as a highly sentimental person. I think this is precisely the reason why the author crafted the conclusion paragraph in this way. It allows us to understand Saeng's emotions and her longing for a better life while still holding onto the memories of her past. Overall, the conclusion paragraph effectively captures Saeng's hopes and dreams for the future.

The author concludes this paragraph in the story as it has a pleasing cadence and aims to convey to the readers that regardless of the adversities one faces in life, one should persist in doing what one deems best. Similar to the flower that endures hardships and keeps coming back, one should maintain resilience.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph due to specific associations. The hibiscus evokes memories of Vietnam for her, while the geese represent her current home. Saeng makes a promise to herself: "In the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, I will take that test again." The hibiscus serves as a metaphor for Saeng's childhood. She grew up in Vietnam and later moved to the @LOCATION2. Just as a flower changes, Saeng will also change. When the hibiscus overcomes the cold, dreary winter and blooms, Saeng will know she is ready to retake the test, as the flower symbolizes her journey through change. The geese in the story also represent change; they migrate south in winter to avoid the cold and return home when it's warm. Like the geese, Saeng will avoid the test in winter but feel comfortable taking it in spring.
She stated that she will take the test next year.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, a young girl named Saeng has moved from her native Vietnam to the United States. She was hoping to obtain her driver's license but failed the test. The hibiscus she sees provides her with comfort, as it reminds her of Vietnam. When she buys the hibiscus, her mother is initially concerned about the price. However, upon seeing her daughter's homesickness, her mother becomes understanding. After planting the hibiscus, Saeng watches the geese and realizes that they change their habitat every year. Inspired by the geese and the hibiscus, Saeng promises herself that “in the spring when the snow melts away, the geese return, and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This shows her determination to overcome her setback and embrace a new opportunity.

It also implies that everyone and everything deserves a second chance. In her case, it is the test she wishes to retake. Additionally, by spring, after living in the new location for a couple of months, she will adjust to the new situation. Currently, she is just homesick, even though her new home is now this place. Thus, the hibiscus is beneficial for her; it is something she can hold onto from her past home.

By ending the paragraph in this way, the author intends to symbolize a fresh start in the coming year.

I'm convinced that she included this part in the story to emphasize its significance to her. For example, when she mentions taking the test again in the spring, it implies that she will put in more effort to ensure everything is done correctly. This shows her determination to follow through on matters that hold importance to her. These are my thoughts on the reason behind her inclusion of this paragraph in the story.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for several reasons. Firstly, Saeng failed the test. Secondly, it takes time for a hibiscus to bud. Moreover, taking the test in the snow doesn't seem practical, so the idea of waiting until spring when the hibiscus buds makes for a more fitting end to the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey to readers Saeng's feelings about the hibiscus. It is believed that the author does so to inform the readers that the hibiscus brings good luck to Saeng, and with this good luck, she will pass the test. The author concludes the story with the given paragraph to create an air of suspense, leaving readers speculating about what will unfold next. In the short - story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author's way of ending the story offers readers a sympathetic understanding of Saeng's struggles to live in a foreign country and her longing to return home. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because now Saeng has a goal to work towards. Another reason could be that she has to wait a long time before she can take the test again. The author concludes the story at this point to demonstrate that Saeng is not a quitter. Instead, she has set a specific time to attempt again. The story “Winter Hibiscus” is about a foreign girl who has a fondness for tropical flowers and is attempting to adapt to @LOCATION1. I firmly believe that the author concludes the story with this paragraph to symbolize new beginnings. The hibiscus in the story represents fresh starts. I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph to show that the character is making an effort and desires another chance. She has recognized her mistakes and is ready to start afresh. Even though she failed in trying to grow the hibiscus in winter, she is looking forward to a new beginning when @DATE1 arrives. As stated in the story, “the winter hibiscus” was in the ground, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks familiar to Saeng in the snow. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she believes it will bring her good luck in the test. When she retakes the test, the comfort of her homeland represented by the hibiscus plant will encourage her to pass the driving test. Due to the sense of home, she will surely pass the test upon retaking it and will be accustomed to the area being different from her homeland. She stated that she would retake the test to prove to her mother that she can succeed this time, rather than worrying about her old home. By focusing on the test, she aims to overcome her concerns and achieve a positive outcome.

I firmly believe that this shows hope. She had deeply missed her homeland and found a sense of peace and tranquility when surrounded by the flowers. When she said, “That at least she could hold on to,” referring to the bud, it was evident that she was extremely upset due to homesickness. She yearned for her grandmother washing her hair and inserting a dok mallk into it. Since she had little else to remind her of her homeland apart from the flowers, as the text mentioned, “where was the fine - toothed comb, the hibiscus hedge, the well, her gentle grandmother,” she was missing all these things. Placing her in this situation made her miss not only the people but also the beautiful aspects of her homeland. The flower ensures that she always carries a part of home with her.

In the last paragraph, the author uses the statement “when they come back, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, I will take that test.” After moving from her homeland, Vietnam, to the United States, Saeng felt homesick. However, she found comfort when she came across a flower that reminded her of her time in her homeland. The plant made her recall her grandmother's smell. When she returned home to her mother, she showed the flower to her, and they planted it together. This gave Saeng a sense of relief. That's why she vowed to take the test when winter ended and spring arrived, as the feeling of home within her provided her with encouragement and strength. It also demonstrates that even in a new area, there is always something that can make one remember the time spent in their place of origin.

The author concludes the story in this way to illustrate her determination to pass the test. Just as birds can fly south, she believes she can pass the test. This conclusion emphasizes her resolve and implies that she has the ability to overcome the challenge presented by the test.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is done for multiple reasons. Firstly, it shows that Saeng retains hope and believes she can correct her situation. Secondly, it indicates that Saeng will continue to attempt to adapt to her surroundings and make friends. Additionally, Saeng is determined to pass the test the next time she takes it. Finally, it emphasizes the conflict and how Saeng overcame it.

In my view, the author ended the story with this paragraph because life goes on. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the character is not overly concerned about when the test will be retaken; instead, she is focused on the plants she has selected. I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph for several reasons. Firstly, it conveys the message of not giving up. I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph to end on a happy and motivating note. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes with the statement, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes with the line, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again."
