In the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author concludes with the paragraph "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, than I will take that test again." The author ended the story by stating that Saeng will retake the driving test in spring to make a point. The author concludes the story with this line to illustrate that, much like the hibiscus adapting and struggling to survive in a non - native land, Saeng will persevere. She won't abandon her fight to pass the test and become part of her new country. Throughout the story, this is supported when her mother comments on the hibiscus by the lake, saying, “It’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters” (Ho @NUM1). Here, the author draws a parallel between the hibiscus' struggle in a foreign land and Saeng's life. The main reason she said that is that she believes time brings change. She essentially implies that as time passes and circumstances shift, her performance could also improve. The author ends the story in this way to emphasize the significance of the plant to the readers. The author concludes the story in this way to set up a spin - off. In my opinion, it implies that when spring arrives, she will attempt again, enabling both her and her plant to have a new beginning. I believe this is an excellent way to end the story.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” for multiple reasons. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng says that when she returns, she will retake the test. This implies that her time there was a test of sorts. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author ended the narrative with that paragraph to convey that Saeng is finally beginning to adapt to her new home. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because now Saeng has a goal to strive for. The author concludes the story in this way due to the significance of the hibiscus to Saeng. For her, the hibiscus symbolizes strength and comfort. I'm of the opinion that the author ended the story with the line “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the gesse return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” as it encapsulates the story's entire theme. The author concludes the story with this paragraph due to her remorse for her actions. The test she described involved using the twenty dollars they had to buy something. After reading “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, I'm convinced that Ho ended the story with that paragraph to reinforce her theme of overcoming obstacles. Initially, after failing her driving test, Saeng was extremely disheartened and uncertain if she'd ever pass. However, seeing a hibiscus plant reminded her of her home in Vietnam, which served as an inspiration. Secondly, when she purchased the plant, her mother was somewhat annoyed because of its high cost. But upon seeing how much joy the plant brought to Saeng, her mother forgave her. Finally, as Saeng was digging a hole for the hibiscus to grow, it motivated her to retake the test as she had overcome the challenges of bringing the plant home and making it thrive. Thus, I believe Ho ended “Winter Hibiscus” to align with her concept of overcoming obstacles.

The final paragraph of the story conveys the theme of determination. The hibiscus serves as a reminder that her “home” was her former life, yet she misses certain aspects in her new life. Through this reminder, she gains determination. She eventually realizes that she has found a new sense of home as things around her have become familiar, like the V - formation of the geese. Although she loved her old home, she understands that it's time to move forward. The last paragraph doesn't merely signify retaking a driving test; it symbolizes the resolve to embrace her new home and life.

She will take that test again. The hibiscus and the snow have given her confidence. When the snow melts and the hibiscus starts to bud, she will try again. She is growing along with the hibiscus, and overall, she will have enough confidence to take the test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to inform readers about what transpired in the story and to convey its possible meaning in relation to the narrative. The sentence implies that when spring arrives and the snow melts, the plants will emerge and start budding. By the next class or school year, the character will gather the courage to take the test again. This is the meaning of the sentence in the story and how it can be related to different elements in various ways.

In "@CAPS1 Ho"'s "Winter Hibiscus", the final paragraph reads, "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This paragraph draws a comparison between Saeng and the hibiscus. It demonstrates Saeng's resilience, similar to the flower's strength. She is determined to retake the test next year and achieve success. Moreover, taking the test offers her comfort and evokes memories of home.

He ended the paragraph in such a way either to entice the reader to continue reading or to illustrate the comparison between the flower and Saeng. The quote "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" shows that the flower can endure the winter and make a comeback. Saeng failed the test once and is now resolved to retake it. This indicates that both the flower and Saeng possess the motivation and integrity to bounce back.

I believe the author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” because it shows that the hibiscus symbolizes a new beginning for Saeng. After failing her driving test, seeing the hibiscus provided her with comfort in a moment of disappointment, a connection to her past experiences, and the confidence to overcome obstacles. When the narrator says “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again,” it implies a fresh start, suggesting that the hibiscus represents Saeng. Thus, this is why I think the author chose to end the story with this paragraph.

The last line in “Winter Hibiscus” is included to establish a connection between Saeng and the hibiscus flower. Despite failing the driving test on her first attempt, Saeng decides to retake it in the spring. Just like Saeng, the hibiscus is out of place and must survive the winter to bloom again in the spring. This parallels Saeng's determination to retake the driving test and succeed. Additionally, both Saeng and the flower are unaccustomed to the conditions in @LOCATION1 and must endure the winter months. This further emphasizes the connection between the girl and the flower. In conclusion, the last line serves to conclude the story by highlighting the relationship between Saeng and the hibiscus.

I believe the author concludes the story with this statement because they are determined to adapt to the new country and its surroundings. Throughout the story, the author expresses homesickness. The author spots a plant native to their homeland and spends over @NUM1 on it. Their mother is incredulous. The author is reluctant to tell their mother the real reason for buying the plant, fearing that they will become emotional. The last sentence indicates that the author is making an effort to adjust to the new environment.

The author concludes the story with the given paragraph to present a conclusion that encapsulates the narrative. In the story, the author describes the hibiscus as a "comfort in time of distress," a pastime or activity the protagonist enjoys in their leisure time. As stated in @ORGANIZATION1, these are the reasons the author chose to end the story with that paragraph.

The author ends the story with the specified paragraph to convey a message. It emphasizes the significant and familiar elements in Saeng's life that provided her comfort, essentially suggesting that she will retake the test once she recovers. The winter hibiscus, a plant Saeng associated with her life back home throughout the story, evoked a profound sense of loss when she saw it, as described: "a wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her." Initially, seeing the plant made it difficult for Saeng to soothe her emotions as she realized how much she missed her old life. The plant is mentioned in the final paragraph because, when it blooms in spring, the winter hibiscus will help fill the emotional gap and encourage Saeng to attempt the test again. Similarly, the geese are mentioned, though in a different manner. Unlike the winter hibiscus, it took time for the geese to become "through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now." Saeng mentions this to acclimate to the unfamiliar aspects of her life and come to terms with her failed test. By referring to these things in the last paragraph, Saeng uses both familiar and foreign objects to illustrate her acceptance of failure.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it conveys the story's meaning. Life persists regardless of circumstances, as exemplified by the hibiscus, which will return in spring. The hibiscus serves as a symbol for Saeng's life. Typically, this plant does not survive the winter, yet this particular one did. Saeng's mother remarks, "It's flowers aren't as pretty, but it's strong enough to make it through the winter months here..." Saeng and her mother are akin to the plant; they are resilient and will continue their lives despite being in a new environment. The author chose to end the story with this paragraph because, beyond the literal return of the hibiscus each spring, it implies that Saeng and her mother, like the hibiscus, will persevere and continue living.

The author opts to conclude the story in a profound and interconnected manner, ending on a theme of rebirth and second - chances. When Saeng vows, "when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return, when the Hibiscus is blooming, I will take the test again," the author links the concepts of a new country, second chances, and rebirth. The melting of snow and the arrival of spring can be associated with rebirth, while the return of the geese symbolizes a second chance, which directly relates to Saeng's opportunity for a retake. Moreover, the author shows that Saeng is adapting to the new country, indicating a sense of hope. This suggests that there is optimism for her test.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey the moral of the tale. I hold this view because in the story, it mentions that orchids, lanno bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vires surrounded the protagonist. These flowers are described as surrounding her as a test of her @CAPS1. The author uses this imagery to ensure the readers grasp the underlying message of the story.

I believe the author reaches this conclusion in the story because it contains crucial information. The story involves her mother, who loves gardening. The character wishes to work in the garden, have a proper job in this field, just like her mother.

Saeng believes she has failed due to missing her grandmother. The hibiscus plant she purchases evokes the scent of her grandmother. Saeng spent over @MONEY1 on the plant to feel a bit more at home. She left her country in a flash, feeling she had little time. Her grandmother would want her to be strong and not cry when thinking about being away. Saeng should focus on the positive and smile when remembering the past. She wants to pass the test. Next time the hibiscus buds, she must refrain from crying.

I think the author includes details about the time the story takes place and the weather to give readers a sense of the setting. It also indicates how long the character will wait, such as until the snow melts and the geese leave and return. This is why I believe the author provides these descriptions.

In my opinion, this passage is about the winter hibiscus. The hibiscus plants are tall and lush, surrounding the garden. Their lush green leaves are dotted with vermilion flowers. When she reached the hibiscus, she gently reached out and touched a petal.

The author ended the story in this way to leave the reader with a final thought and to symbolize rebirth. When Saeng says, “... this hibiscus is budding ...” (Ho @NUM1), she implies that they will start anew in spring. This leaves the reader with a thought about Saeng's ability to overcome life in a new place. Additionally, it ties up @CAPS1's feelings and experiences since moving, as seen in the statement “... I will take the test again” (Ho @NUM1), showing she will keep trying in her new home. In conclusion, this quote as the last paragraph shows that Saeng will continue to overcome the challenges of her new environment.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as she wishes to instill hope for the future. The budding of the hibiscus in spring is what Saeng anticipates. It offers her the hope that she can retake and pass the test. This is evident when she says, “... and if this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” During winter, Saeng hopes to improve, and when the hibiscus buds, she'll know it's time to try again. Saeng views spring as a new beginning, a time to overcome her obstacle. It's possible that the obstacle or test is to refrain from crying when she thinks about her former life in Vietnam. When she achieves this, she, like the hibiscus, is growing.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for a single primary reason, which is to convey a particular message or bring the narrative to a fitting close. This conclusion serves to wrap up the story in a way that leaves an impression on the reader, perhaps tying up loose ends or highlighting a key theme.

The author is demonstrating that Saeng has a strong desire to continue her mother's gardening. She aims to inherit the traditions of the elder generation and carry on what her mother initiated. By doing so, Saeng not only honors her mother but also keeps a part of her heritage alive. This act of taking over the gardening is a way for Saeng to connect with her roots and continue the family's legacy.

I firmly believe that the author ended the story with this paragraph to highlight the main character's remarkable persistence. This belief is grounded in the story's beginning, where the character reveals that she failed the driver's test while walking home. In the final paragraph, she declares that after winter ends, she will retake the test when her hibiscus blooms. Her unwavering persistence enables her to persevere through life, much like a plant striving to survive the harsh winter. This tenacity is a valuable trait that allows her to face challenges head - on and keep moving forward.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the character wants to do better next time. The paragraph implies that she can attempt the task every year to get it right and impress her mother. This shows her determination and eagerness to meet her mother's expectations. In conclusion, this is the significance I find in the paragraph, as it showcases the character's motivation and the importance of family approval in her life.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author most likely ends the narrative with the given quote to illustrate that Saeng perceives the hibiscus as more than mere flowers; it is also a repository of memories. For Saeng, the winter hibiscus is like a storybook. Simply by smelling the flower, it unlocks wonderful recollections of the precious time she spent with her “gentle grandmother” in her first home. The author uses the flower to demonstrate to the reader how a simple object can trigger memories, thoughts, and so on. The last sentence, with evidence from the story, clearly shows that Saeng deeply cares about her past. To fit into her current life, she must not forget who she was. By keeping the hibiscus in her garden, she has a beautiful reminder of her roots. Therefore, this reasoning is the likely assumption for why the author ended the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the selected paragraph.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for several reasons. For instance, when the character says “this hibiscus is budding,” it conveys a sense of hope, indicating a new beginning or a fresh start. I believe this is the idea the author aims to convey. Evidently, it was challenging for the author to adjust to her new country. For example, she was disappointed that the hibiscus was not the same as the one in her homeland. Despite feeling nostalgic, this paragraph assures the reader that the author is willing to give her new country another chance, showing her resilience and openness to new experiences.

The author concludes the story with the specific paragraph for multiple reasons. The last paragraph states, “when they come back ... I will take the test again” (Ho @NUM1). The main character, already distraught about failing her driving test, is also longing for her homeland. The buds of the flowers offer her hope and, essentially, the strength to retake the test. Earlier, when she was in the flower shop, after smelling and seeing the flowers, “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her ... And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept” (Ho @NUM2). Clearly, these flowers hold great significance for the main character. They transport her back to her home - country, which she was suddenly separated from and misses dearly. They give her hope and remind her of the things she loves, such as her grandmother. In conclusion, the author chose to end the story with this paragraph because it represents what matters most to the main character.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show that the main character loves the flowers deeply. They mean a great deal to her. When she failed her driving test, she was sad, but the flowers made her feel better. Now that it's snowing, she waits for spring. When the flowers bloom again, she will have the faith to take the driving test once more. The flowers serve as a source of comfort and motivation for her, helping her overcome the disappointment of the failed test and look forward to a better outcome in the future.

The author concluded the sentence to inform the readers that Saeng would return to the hibiscus and continue to care for it. This ending emphasizes the significance of the hibiscus in Saeng's life and her emotional connection to it. It also implies that the hibiscus will continue to be a part of her life, symbolizing her roots and memories.

In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus", a teenager named Saeng relocates from Vietnam to the United States. Subsequently, she takes a driver's test but fails. However, she finds solace in the memories of her homeland. The last paragraph quotes Saeng's silent vow: "When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. Saeng was deeply upset about failing the test and was reminded of her homeland and the adaptations she had to make during the move. The hibiscus plant offers Saeng hope to persevere through difficult times. Just as winter is a period of hardship and sorrow for the plant, failing the test and being away from her true home are Saeng's moments of distress. The end of winter presents both the plant and Saeng with an opportunity for a fresh start and renewed hope. If Saeng continues to draw comfort from her past, she will find it easier to overcome hardships.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to pique the readers' curiosity and to demonstrate that the protagonist is not going to abandon her aspirations. This ending implies a sense of determination and resilience, leaving the readers with a feeling that the character will persist in her pursuit.

In my opinion, Minfong Ho ends the story by discussing the test that Saeng failed and her vow to retake it. In the story, the test symbolizes a step towards moving on and starting a new life, leaving the old behind. However, Saeng was unable to achieve this initially. She spent all her money on a flower because it held precious memories of her homeland. As the story progresses, I believe Saeng realizes that she can embrace both her old and new lives. The author ends the story in this way because Saeng genuinely wants to try again. She desires to please her mother and herself, and she yearns to move forward and begin her new life.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph because Saeng realizes she needs more time. If she takes a break and focuses on what she needs to do, she will be able to pass the test. This shows that Saeng is self - aware and understands that patience and preparation are key to achieving her goal.

The author concludes the story in this manner as it allows for the expansion of the narrative into a sequel about Saeng's success. By ending the story this way, the author showcases Saeng's unwavering determination; she will stop at nothing until she passes the test. Saeng is struggling to adapt to her new lifestyle as the familiar plants and landscapes from her homeland are no longer present. Her determination is evident when her mother discovers that she spent @NUM1 dollars on a similar plant. The mother's response, stating that their entire garden is worth less than @NUM1 dollars, further emphasizes Saeng's strong attachment to the symbols of her past and her resolve to make a new life for herself.

The sentence serves as the conclusion of the passage, demonstrating that when the hibiscus begins to bud and a new season commences, Saeng will transform into a new individual and be capable of taking the test. In this sentence, the cold snow, departing geese, and potted hibiscus can all symbolize Saeng and her current circumstances. They are either cold, on the verge of leaving, or restricted, mirroring Saeng's feelings. However, when a new season arrives, the geese return, and the hibiscus is no longer confined to a pot, Saeng will also mature and be ready to take the test. Placing this sentence at the end shows the extent to which Saeng can grow because she has the hibiscus, which is growing alongside her.
The author concludes the story with the given sentence. The author implies that when winter ends, it will be time to resume gardening and take the test related to the planted plant.

I believe the author concluded the story with a paragraph about Saeng taking the test again at another time for a specific reason. Saeng is essentially telling herself that she needs more time to get ready for the test. Once she has sufficient time to prepare, she will attempt the test again. This, in my opinion, is the motivation behind the author's choice to use this paragraph as the conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the budding hibiscus will inspire the protagonist to attempt the test again. To pass the test, she wishes to feel at home and draw on memories of her home to encourage her to try once more. Hence, this is the reason the author ends the story with the last paragraph.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph about taking the test again to illustrate that although the narrator may be distressed about being in a new place, she will persevere. The narrator becomes upset upon realizing that the hibiscus is not the same as those from her old home. This distress likely stems from her longing for the things she was accustomed to before. By using this paragraph, the author shows that the narrator is resilient and will not give up on recreating the way things were. Additionally, it shows her willingness to adapt to her new home. The author does this to convey the message that one should keep trying at something they love. The narrator will keep trying when the geese fly back and the hibiscus is budding. Thus, the author is advocating for perseverance in the face of failure and setting goals to never give up.
I believe there are multiple reasons why the author concludes the story with this paragraph.

I reckon the author wraps up the story with this paragraph 'cause he's aware he messed up on the test. He's saying that when spring rolls around again, he'll be ready to take the test. I can tell it's spring 'cause he mentioned when the snow melts.

Upon moving to America, she witnessed the beautiful spring flowers. A particular blossom, the hibiscus, caught her eye. Intrigued, she went to the florist to check if they had it. Back in her homeland, these hibiscus grew wild, peeping out from the cracks in old walls. The blossom reminded her of her grandmother with her long, freshly - washed gray hair.

In the passage “Winter Hibiscus” by Monfong Ho, the quote “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, I will take the test again” symbolizes a new journey in the new country where she resides. In the test, Saeng experiences a personal conflict as she misses her homeland, as evidenced by her statement “I – failed the test.” This test holds more significance than just a simple failure; it is a measure of her ability to function in the new country, and unfortunately, she failed. Analyzing the “when they came back…” quote in depth, the snow can be seen as her obstacles, and the hibiscus represents herself. When the obstacles are removed, and she transforms into a stronger individual, she will attempt the test once more.
She is going to return to the place where her journey began. It's a cyclical process, and she will find herself back at the starting point the following year.

I am of the opinion that the author concludes the story with this paragraph: “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This is because the budding flower would instill confidence in her regarding everything. The flower reminds her of past memories of her homeland, and it is as if she has a piece of home in her new abode. An example is “Not like the kind we had before,” which indicates that the new hibiscus is similar yet different from the one in her home country, thus evoking memories of home. This is the reason I believe the author ends the story in this manner.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng will not give up but rather overcome the problem. It is an excellent way to end the story as the entire narrative revolves around overcoming difficulties. If Saeng were to give up, it would undermine the story. Just as she managed to move away from her homeland, she will eventually pass the test. The mother also overcame obstacles, such as leaving her homeland and having to plant new plants. She clearly misses the old ones, as evident from her knowledge of her gift. Like Saeng, she can handle these challenges, and Saeng will do the same when she takes the test again.

In the story, a transformation is imminent. Winter will give way to spring, the snow will melt and disappear, the geese will return, the hibiscus will bud, and Saeng will also undergo a change and mature. Saeng is comparable to the hibiscus plant; just as the plant is out of place on the road, Saeng is out of place in the new country and must adapt. The plant looks different in the United States compared to Vietnam as it has matured and grown. This is what Saeng must do in the new country. For instance, Saeng noticed the difference in the appearance of the plant in the shop window compared to her home country, which made her realize how different she appeared as well. Placing the paragraph at the end shows that she has already matured and grown. Putting it at the beginning would not have the same impact. The hibiscus plant endured the harsh winter, and Saeng can do the same. She made a silent vow to take the test again once she has matured, just like the things around her.

The author concludes the story with the given paragraph for multiple reasons. Firstly, the author aims to conclude the story without leaving the readers with any questions about what happens next. In Minfong Ho's story “Winter Hibiscus”, I believe the elements included are there to keep the reader questioning. The author concludes the story with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This ending choice serves to illustrate the mood shift throughout the narrative. I firmly believe the author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with this particular paragraph for several reasons. Firstly, it demonstrates the girl's unwavering determination. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that the story or the characters within have an affinity for nature. The author wrote the last paragraph to offer hope to both Saeng and the reader. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it aligns well with the overall narrative and effectively summarizes it. In the story, the hibiscus holds great significance for Saeng. The author concludes the story with that paragraph because it indicates that she cannot work in the garden during winter. The author decided to conclude the story with that paragraph as it symbolizes Saeng's determination to try again. I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph because regardless of what she said or did, she had to get the flower. She checks if her plant will survive the winter, just like the ones from her home. She believes that things will remain the same. In the end, her hope lies in the plant's ability to endure, symbolizing her own resilience in adapting to a new environment.

It marks the beginning of a new life. She has a new school and a new plant. It seems as though she has a connection with the plant. As the plant grows, she becomes stronger and more confident. She stated that when they return and the hibiscus is budding, she will be ready for that test. This shows that her growth is intertwined with the plant's, and she is looking forward to facing the challenges ahead.

I think the author ends the story in this way because it demonstrates that she won't give up and will give her new country a chance. By ending with this, she conveys that she will be as strong as the flower and will stay regardless of the circumstances. She will be there, in that very spot, to witness the flower grow back. Throughout the story, we are provided with background information about a girl, Saeng, who desperately misses her true home. When we first meet young Saeng, she is in a florist's shop, merely looking at flowers. Soon, we learn that she is not just looking at them but seeing pieces of her home and past. She then buys a hibiscus, a flower native to Vietnam. After realizing that she has just failed a test, it becomes more evident that buying the flower is a way for her to cope with her new situation in @LOCATION1 and find comfort in her past. The author can conclude the story with that statement because it implies moving forward without being attached to the past. In the spring, Saeng will have a new home and draw strength from her past, which is what I believe the final paragraph implies.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as Saeng is resolved to pass the test. She is aware that when spring arrives and the hibiscus starts budding, she will retake it. Presumably, she wishes to retake the test because the hibiscus reminds her of her homeland, instilling confidence in her. She believes she can pass it the next time. The hibiscus fills her with happiness and a sense of being overwhelmed, motivating her to retake the test. She is certain she will perform better next time.

In my view, the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it demonstrates that if a flower can bloom in various places and endure natural changes, so can she. I reckon she's saying that once winter is over, she'll be ready for the winter test again. I assume this because they weren't prepared for winter when they were planting. The author concludes "Winter Hibiscus" with this paragraph to emphasize a new life and fresh opportunities for the main character. Additionally, the physical action of "the hibiscus is budding" represents rebirth. In winter, the plant is dormant and less vibrant, but in spring, it showcases rebirth through the colorful buds. In Minfong Ho's story "Winter Hibiscus", a girl has recently moved to a new country and is struggling to adapt to the new land and its people. I hold this view because Saeng thinks to herself, "almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her." This indicates that she has finally found comfort and confidence, similar to geese adapting to a new area and then returning. At the end of her paragraph, she concludes by stating that she will look forward to the end of winter. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it demonstrates the character's attempt to adapt to her new surroundings. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it continues to demonstrate Saeng's strong determination to retake the test and achieve a passing grade this time. By ending the story with this paragraph, the author creates suspense, likely in anticipation of a sequel.

In the short - story "Winter Hibiscus", a young Vietnamese girl moves to @LOCATION1 and fails her driver's test. I'm of the opinion that the author includes this passage in the story to symbolize determination and @LOCATION1. In "The Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the writer concludes the story with a final paragraph. In Minfong Ho's story "Winter Hibiscus", the author concludes with the last sentence to indicate that the plant - growing season has ended. In "Winter Hibiscus", the author concludes with Saeng stating "I will take that test again". This implies that Saeng will be prepared as soon as spring arrives and her hibiscus is in full bloom. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author includes the last paragraph to convey that the main character, Saeng, retains hope and has not abandoned her new lifestyle. Author MiNfoNg Ho concludes the story with Saeng silently vowing to herself, “When they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” The reason is that when the plant begins to blossom, Saeng will feel more confident and comfortable. The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concluded the story with the paragraph “when they came back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The reason for this ending is that she bought the flower after failing the test, and she intends to retake the test when the flower blooms.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author probably selected this as the final paragraph to help the reader grasp the story's message. In Minfong Ho's short story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author includes a paragraph at the end stating that the main character, Saeng, will retake her driving test. Throughout the story, she reminisces about her home in Vietnam, her grandmother, and the flowers there, asking, “Where was me...hibiscus hedge?... Her gentle grandmother?” At the flower shop, Saeng finds a hibiscus, a flower also found in Vietnam. Seeing how it has adapted to survive the winter, while planting it in her backyard, she vows to pass the driving test next spring. She wants to adapt to her new environment and live without excessive longing for home. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey the true meaning of the hibiscus. The author concludes the story with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melts and the geese return and this hibiscus budding, then I will take that test again.” The conclusion is significant as it is crucial for Saeng to feel at home. The author concludes the story with that paragraph. The reason is that she is eager to repeat the same activities next year. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus offers comfort. Saeng failed her driving test and was new to the place. The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it establishes a new - found connection between the hibiscus and Saeng's circumstances in a foreign country. The text states, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, become familiar to her.” This shows the adaptation Saeng has undergone since coming to @LOCATION1. The author ends the story with this paragraph to illustrate that, like the hibiscus, Saeng will adapt to the challenges of @LOCATION1. The hibiscus inspires her to persevere and retake the license test, just as the plant endures the winter.

The author concludes the story in this manner because Saeng finds comfort in the hibiscus flower. The flower evokes memories of her homeland and her grandmother. As the story describes, “the familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother's long gray hair.” This indicates that although she misses her homeland, she keeps it close to her heart wherever she goes. The text also mentions that “it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers.” Saeng appears to have a close connection with nature and its appealing qualities. After failing the test, she buys the “@CAPS1 Malik” flower for comfort. She and her mother decide to plant it in their garden, and during this process, Saeng gains a significant boost of confidence to retake the test.

She makes a comparison between the paragraph and the story in the context of school. In this comparison, taking the test is equated with making new friends and performing well in tests and classes. The paragraph contains the statement “Then I will take that test again.” This is the reason she draws a parallel between the paragraph and school, suggesting that just as the character in the paragraph is determined to retake the test, one should be persistent in the school - related challenges of making friends and excelling academically.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to underscore Saeng's resolve to overcome the hurdles from her past experiences. For instance, the story begins with Saeng taking a “test.” While in the greenhouse, as she relives her memories, she starts to break down. The text describes, “A wave of loss so deep and strong it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her.” After this, she buys a plant and takes it home to her mother, informing her that she “failed.” Her mother shows understanding and supports Saeng's vow to retake the “test.” The narrator emphasizes Saeng's determination to move past the difficulties of her past and embrace the future.

Her schoolwork was the reason she was studying flowers in a green garden. She failed the test, and when spring arrives and the flowers bloom, she will retake it. She can then conduct more studies to pass and avoid having to take it again. It seems she is also looking forward to spring so she can enjoy the flowers and continue growing and studying.

I believe the author concluded the story with that specific paragraph to show that Saeng, originally from Vietnam who moved to the United States, was not giving up. She missed her home greatly as everything was different. “It’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. “I mean, not like the kind we had at - at...”. She found herself too emotional to say “at home”. Once Saeng realized she was starting to adapt to life in the US, she decided to take the driver's test again. “When they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” In conclusion, the author used this paragraph to depict Saeng's perseverance.

I think the author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng appears to feel more at ease when she sees the geese and plants the hibiscus in winter, preventing it from dying. As the story states, “... their faint banks clear and - yes - familiar to Saeng now”. This seems to explain how she feels after seeing the geese fly overhead, as she used to witness this in Vietnam. Also, when she says, “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding”, she gains more confidence as she feels like she's back in Vietnam. Overall, this is why the author concludes the story with that paragraph, to convey Saeng's sense of comfort and connection.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with this paragraph to let the reader imagine what will happen to Saeng when spring arrives. This enables the reader to engage their imagination and connect with the story. Another reason is to give the reader hope that Saeng might pass the test next time. It's also a positive way to end the story, leaving the reader with an optimistic outlook.

The author ended the story with that particular paragraph because, like the geese that return, the character will come back to try again. The author wanted to convey that the character might not have completed everything she intended to do, and to show the reader the character's determination and ambition. It also demonstrates that the character's spirit cannot be broken by one winter, and she will persevere until she achieves her goals.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with Saeng vowing to retake the test. This is done to convey that, even in challenging circumstances and new environments, one should never succumb to despair. There are always elements that can offer comfort. Throughout the story, glimpses of Saeng's home are provided through her memories, allowing readers to understand the difficult day she is having. The author describes these warm, comforting memories to contrast with the cold, bitter reality of her current situation. For instance, when Saeng “closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs,” she recalls a memory of her grandmother, which saddens her as she thinks of her home and loss. The author builds up Saeng's despair and distress leading to the final paragraph. This final paragraph is significant as it represents hope. When Saeng says, “then I will take that test again,” one can sense her hope. Additionally, the author aims to express that there is still structure and stability in a changing world, and one can find solace in simple things. Saeng mentions, “the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” indicating that there are reliable elements that can provide security when one feels lost. The author uses this last paragraph to balance the despair in the story, emphasizing the need for hope and showing that there are always things that can offer hope and security.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph to complete the narrative. At the end of the paragraph, the character is visualizing and putting effort into the hibiscus, showing her appreciation for the plant. The author also wants to provide more evidence to the story. For example, the statement “in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” includes the winter period for the plant. As the seasons change from winter to spring, the plant comes back to life, and the character Saeng will also regain her connection with it and visit it. This conclusion ties together the themes of renewal and the character's determination in the face of change.

The author made it seem as if he didn't like something, but in reality, he loved flowers and enjoyed working in the area with the people. His mother was also involved in some way. He liked to see the people around him getting on with their lives and coming back to the place because they liked it. This shows that despite the initial appearance, there was a deep - seated affection for the place and the activities associated with it. The author's portrayal of these feelings adds depth to the story, highlighting the positive aspects of the environment and the relationships within it.

The author includes this part at the end of the story to demonstrate the character's deep affection for the plant and how it evokes memories of her childhood. Evidence of her love for the plant can be found in descriptions such as “rich scent” (Paragraph Minfong Ho) and “It felt smooth and cool” (paragraph Minfong Ho). Regarding the connection to her childhood, she realizes that she had forgotten certain things but they resurfaced. For example, she had not even realized she had known something but had forgotten it, and when she came back, she could “reed” (presumably read or experience in some way). Based on these aspects, it is reasonable to conclude that the author adds this part at the end to emphasize the character - plant relationship and the link to her past.

I firmly believe that the author left this as the last thing for the reader to read, intending it to be a powerful message. In the story, the girl has moved to a completely new environment and culture. The only familiar thing to her is a wild - growing flower from her previous home. Her little vow to herself serves as a reminder not to give up. It encourages her to keep going and to be open - minded about new experiences, as one never knows what they can learn. This girl didn't simply give up; her plant symbolizes a new beginning. Just as the plant starts anew, she decides to do the same. It can also be seen as a representation of her life itself. In the text, there are indications that suggest this new start, making it clear that the author uses this ending to inspire readers with the message of hope and resilience.

I believe the author wrote in this way because perhaps in winter, she truly feels she can reveal her true self. However, when spring arrives, she is like a flower that has withered throughout the winter. This shows a contrast in her self - expression between different seasons.

The author ends the story with this paragraph. In the preceding paragraph, they were discussing the “winter hibiscus” and the geese. So, the author simply writes a concluding paragraph to wrap up the story, leaving the reader with a positive feeling.

In Minfong Ho's “The Winter Hibiscus,” the story details the challenges Saeng faced upon moving to a different country. Saeng failed her driving test and was reminded of her homeland by some tropical flowers. At the end of the story, the author has Saeng vow, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, it's the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” This part is crucial as it showcases Saeng's growth and hope for change, similar to the geese's return and the hibiscus blossoming. It also indicates that Saeng will not give up and will adapt to the new environment, just as the plants and geese do. This conclusion is significant for readers as it sums up Saeng's thoughts and hopes for the future while adjusting to her new surroundings.

There could be multiple reasons for the author to conclude the story with this paragraph. I think the author aimed to provide an interesting fact about what happens to hibiscus when it snows. For instance, the author explains the growth process of hibiscus, including the requirements such as sunlight, water, soil, and waste management. Maybe the author thought that by explaining how the growth process restarts after snowfall, it would be a fitting conclusion for the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because Saeng mentions failing a test and decides to retake it when spring returns. The last paragraph states, “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again.” However, the story doesn't clarify which test Saeng is referring to.
The individual stated that she would wait until spring to retake the test. The purpose of this delay is to determine whether her preference for the bitter melon over the Big - Mac persists.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because of the mention of taking the test again. What is meant by this is that she will have to repeat the same actions next year. Similar to how the hibiscus adapted to its environment, she must adapt to life. Additionally, she is advocating to do one's best as living life to the fullest is the essence of existence. Thus, it serves as a fitting conclusion for the story.

In my opinion, the reason the author ends the story in such a way is that it provides an open - ended conclusion. This style also implies that there could potentially be more to the story in the future.

The author concludes that during spring, when the snow melts and the flowers bloom, it brings a sense of the essence of spring at home. This situation allows her to relax. Moreover, spring is a more beautiful season as all the flowers are in bloom, and a particular flower reminds her of the blessings of home.

Saeng made a silent vow to herself. She decided that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus starts to bud, she will retake the test. Saeng intends to wait to take the test until she is confident that she will pass it and obtain her license. She desires the license so that she can drive wherever she wants, eliminating the need for her mother to take her everywhere. However, she has to wait until the snow has melted before retaking the test.

The paragraph indicates that Saeng has deep affection for her plants. She takes pleasure in them and values the time she spends with them. In the last paragraph, she expresses her eagerness for winter to end so that her plants can start budding and she can once again enjoy their presence.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it effectively ties all the elements together. I believe the author also uses it to imply that in the spring, she will pass the test. I'm particularly fond of the part where she says "In the spring, when the snows melt...". This is because it clearly conveys what she desires and how she is determined to achieve it.

The author likely employs this paragraph to illustrate the character setting a goal for the cycle to restart. Geese are used as a symbol of spring, when the character would once again commence preparations for the “test”. The budding hibiscus in this paragraph represents hope, as it signifies the start of a new cycle and serves as an object of reminiscence in the story. In conclusion, this concluding paragraph utilizes various symbols and devices to convey hope, evoke good memories, and suggest a fresh start.

She would grow some flowers and water them when the geese return to her pond. This simple act of nurturing the flowers and observing the return of the geese adds a sense of tranquility and renewal to the scene.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph for multiple reasons. One reason is to truly convey the meaning of the flower. Another is to express the theme. For instance, at the end of the paragraph, it says “Then I will take that test again.” This relates the small topic of the driving test to the larger topic of the flower, which in turn connects it to the theme of adjusting and persevering until one adjusts. That last paragraph was extremely crucial to the theme and meaning of the story.

I believe Minfong Ho concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” with the line “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to illustrate how past memories can be transformed into hope and determination. After failing her driving test, Saeng encounters the hibiscus, and memories of her homeland and grandmother overwhelm her. She purchases the plant and places it in the vegetable garden. After planting, Saeng witnesses a flock of Canada geese flying overhead. Drawing on her memories of her old home and family and applying them to her new environment, Saeng vows to retake the test and try again. By ending the story with this paragraph, the author demonstrates that Saeng will not give up.

The author concludes the story to show that Saeng is prepared to embrace her new life. When the geese return and the hibiscus begins to bud, she feels at home. It is when she feels more at home that she will be ready to retake the test. As the text states, “when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Clearly, the geese and hibiscus evoke memories of her home. Once she feels at home, she will feel at ease. This is why the author concluded the story with this passage.

The author concluded the story with that paragraph because it restates the main idea of the story, enabling readers to understand its essence. By using that concluding paragraph, the author effectively wraps up the narrative and ensures that the central message is conveyed to the readers.

The author reveals that she has failed the test. It is still winter, and the hibiscus is in the process of regrowing its lovely petals. She tells her mother that she will not take the test again until the hibiscus starts budding and spring returns. This indicates her determination to wait for a more favorable time, symbolized by the blooming of the hibiscus and the arrival of spring.

Yes, I firmly believe that this ending concludes the story. After all the events in the story and her learning about gardening from her mother, she recalls what her mother said about the hibiscus and its budding. The ending sentence implies that when spring arrives, she will take the test again. This test will determine whether she has learned enough about gardening from her mother over time. The ending effectively ties up the story by linking her learning experience to a specific event in nature, providing a sense of closure.
The author concludes the story with this paragraph presumably because the grandma passed away when the geese were in flight, or perhaps that's when the flowers began to bloom.

In "Winter Hibiscus", the author included the last paragraph to convey to readers that Saeng will move on while still remembering her old country. Before finding the hibiscus, Saeng deeply missed her homeland. As she said, “It’s - it’s not a real one,” she mumbled. “I mean not like the kind we had at - at...” She found herself too emotional to mention home and burst into tears. She struggled to accept her new country as home. The hibiscus flower brought back vivid memories of her old country, making it harder for her to move forward. One of the blossoms fell, and Saeng gently picked it up and smelled it. She could almost feel her grandmother's freshly - washed long gray hair as she combed it with the fine - toothed buffalo - horn comb. Holding the flower, she finally had a tangible link to home. “Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold onto.” This was the first step towards moving on. Saeng needed time to adjust to her new country. “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many things that she had thought of as strange before had become almost familiar to her now.” Like a hibernating hibiscus, she needed a bit more time. She decided that when the hibiscus emerged from hibernation and was ready to bloom, she would be ready to accept her new country and move on. The time between fall and spring would be enough for her to adapt to her new life. By taking this step, Saeng will move on. The author included the last paragraph so readers can infer that Saeng will take the final steps to accept her new country and move on, while still looking back at her old country through the winter hibiscus.

The story includes this paragraph because at the start, the girl failed the test. When she told her mother, she saw her mother was upset. After they planted the plant, she decided to retake the test, knowing her mother would approve. Also, the story began with her telling her mother about the failed test. If this part were removed, readers might wonder why her mother didn't do anything about the failure. Moreover, when readers learn of the girl's failed test, they will want to know if she retakes it and the reason behind it.

In my opinion, the author ended the story with an open - ended conclusion. The author did this to maintain readers' interest and encourage them to read his other books. Additionally, such an ending leaves room for improvement and the possibility of a sequel.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to demonstrate that Saeng will not give up until she successfully completes the task her mother assigns. Saeng fails the test because, although she buys a beautiful plant, it is extremely expensive. Her mother exclaims, “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much!” Saeng becomes very distraught and realizes she has let her mother down. However, she still plants the winter hibiscus in the ground. “Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the ‘winter hibiscus’ into it.” This shows that despite her failure, she refuses to abandon the hibiscus as it symbolizes her home and is very special to her.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it indicates that the character in the story, Saeng, is beginning to adapt to her new country. At the start of the story, Saeng is homesick and has not adjusted to her new environment. She fails her driver's test and on the way home, she spots a hibiscus in a flower - shop. The hibiscus is significant to her as it reminds her of Vietnam, her home country. For Saeng, it represents comfort in times of disappointment, a connection to her past, and the ability to overcome obstacles. She has struggled to adapt to the changes in her life. The author ends the story with this paragraph to show readers that life will always have changes and obstacles, but there will also always be something or someone to help overcome them. By concluding with this paragraph, the author shows that Saeng uses the hibiscus as a means of overcoming difficulties, and when she is ready and has adjusted, she will retake her driving test.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it conveys that once winter and spring pass and the hibiscus starts budding, the character will start anew and make another attempt. The author implies that Saeng is eager for spring so she can plant her own small garden. This is the reason I believe the author ends the story with this particular paragraph.

This paragraph depicts an action that Saeng will undertake over the course of a year. She is going to develop and transform in time for the retake of the test, which is akin to a rebirth. The girl wishes to be a completely new person by the time the test comes around again. Her mother appears to be annoyed by every action or decision of her daughter. The daughter suddenly realizes the significance of the hibiscus and why it withers. As stated, "... thought the quiet repetition of season upon season." She associates the flower and geese with herself. Throughout the year, the flower goes through phases of dying and then rebirth. Saeng desires to improve after going through a similar phase, just like the flower that blossoms beautifully again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because after Saeng takes her driver's test and is on her way home, she sees a winter hibiscus that is extremely beautiful. She then goes to the store and buys the flower, which costs a large amount of money. When she gets home, her mother is planting vegetables and asks her what it is. Saeng tells the truth, and when her mother learns of the high cost of the flower, she becomes angry at Saeng's extravagance. Despite her mother's anger, Saeng makes a firm decision to keep the flower, presumably because it reminds her of Vietnam. I think the author includes this paragraph because when the geese return and the flowers grow, Saeng will take the test again. When she bought the flower, it had not bloomed yet, so she will wait until it does. This is a way of showing that one should observe the first signs and wait for the right time to take on a challenge. In my opinion, this is a good ending and also poses an interesting question.

The author concludes the text with this paragraph as it shows the author's intention to convey a certain message. The author seems to imply that the character's situation is tied to the cycle of the hibiscus. The character, likely Saeng, has faced a set - back in the form of failing the driver's test. The sight of the hibiscus on the way home from the test becomes a symbol. The hibiscus represents hope and a new beginning. Just as the hibiscus goes through seasons, the character will go through a period of growth and change. The author uses this to show that even in the face of disappointment and the anger of her mother over the expensive flower, the character can find the strength to persevere. When the hibiscus blooms, it will be a sign for the character to retake the test, indicating that growth and opportunity come after a period of waiting and self - improvement.

The author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself...” as it provides the reader with a conclusion. This passage implies that once Saeng has acclimated to her new life in a foreign country, she will attempt her driver's test again. When she becomes familiar with her surroundings, she will feel more at home. Throughout the story, her separation from Vietnam leaves her feeling lonely. The hibiscus plant initially offers her a sense of comfort, as described by “It felt smooth and cool... just as she had known it would feel.” The ending paragraph indicates that Saeng will find more sources of comfort in @LOCATION2 beyond just a plant and a few geese.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because when the “snow does melt and the Geese return,” it will be time to plant and work in the garden more intensively. With snow on the ground, planting is not possible, but the return of the geese signals the appropriate time to sow seeds. The test is to determine if she can achieve a better grade than in previous years.
The author concluded the story with that paragraph because that is the appropriate way to end it, which is why the ending was structured in such a manner.

The author concludes the story with “in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This is done to illustrate that Saeng is adapting to her new country and making decisions, similar to how she did in her homeland. In Vietnam, Saeng used to brush her grandmother's hair, put it into a bun, and place a hibiscus in it, which was one of her traditions. Additionally, when she fetched water from the well, a hibiscus would sometimes be retrieved with the bucket. Thus, the hibiscus was regarded as a comfort object. Now, in the United States, she is attempting to make good use of it while also considering the seasonal patterns in the country. She observes that the geese return in the spring and depart in the winter, and plants begin to grow in the spring. By taking the test again in the spring, it symbolizes that she is ready to start anew, just like the hibiscus that is about to bloom. The potted plant in her garden and Saeng's relocation both signify change, while also serving as a reminder of old traditions and creating space for new ones.
The author included that sentence in the story because she believes it will give her sufficient time to pass the test successfully, and she has an affinity for geese.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to demonstrate the final determination and strength bestowed upon Saeng. It seems as if this plant has served to inspire her to rise again and pass the test. The plant becomes a comforting symbol that reminds her of her homeland. She returned with the plant to show her mother but found herself too tremulous to utter the words “at home,” which indicates her profound longing for home. However, she comes to realize that this is her new home and that everything is gradually becoming more familiar to her.

She concludes with this sentence as it represents a sign of new life. Just as winter, which causes the death of plants and the end of life, is succeeded by spring, which ushers in a new beginning, this is how Saeng feels. After leaving her country and leaving all her memories behind, she feels out of place, like the winter hibiscus. But as spring arrives, she will feel like a new person, ready and capable of taking on challenges. As she stated, “through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now,” she describes that with a new season comes new changes, and she will go on to retake the driver's test.

The author ends the story with that paragraph for multiple reasons. Firstly, it shows that although she has failed this time, more opportunities will present themselves in the future. Secondly, it illustrates that despite the current misfortunes she faces, better times are yet to come. Overall, it was a powerful and effective way to conclude the story.

The author employs symbolism to convey a distinct message. Saeng stated that in the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and the hibiscus is in bud, she will take the test again. The author uses the hibiscus to symbolize Saeng's growth, suggesting that just as the hibiscus matures, she will be ready to take the test once more. By using symbolism, the author enriches the narrative of the story.
She wrote that response to inform everyone that she will be prepared by the time spring arrives. At that point, she will take the test and pass.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as Saeng wishes to resume planting. Saeng's life centers around planting, and her family obtains food from their plants. Throughout the relevant time period, they spend a significant amount of time in the garden, growing crops both for sale and for storage. They save the crops for winter and sell them to acquire the equipment needed to continue their activities. In the paragraph, when she mentions “when they come back,” she is referring to the geese. Saeng adores the sight of geese flying overhead and landing in the yard on beautiful days. Once the snow melts, she yearns to get her hands and knees in the soil and start planting anew. When the hibiscus begins to bud, all other plants start to grow. Saeng's life is deeply intertwined with planting. The author included this paragraph in the story because this is what Saeng desires most.

In the conclusion of “Winter Hibiscus,” Saeng mentions that she will retake her driving test in spring when the snow melts and the geese return. Spring is the time when these events occur, along with the annual budding of the winter hibiscus. Her family relocated from Vietnam to a specific location. Saeng bought a winter hibiscus plant to evoke memories of her childhood. When the plant blooms, she will retake her driving test as it will bring her the hope of a new beginning in her life as a citizen in that location.
In the short - story “Winter Hibiscus,” a young girl named Saeng moves away from home. The story depicts her struggle to adapt to a new lifestyle and the changes that come with it.

The author ends the story with this paragraph to convey to the reader that Saeng will not give up until she passes her driver's test, just as geese do not stop their migration until they reach the south for winter. The author aims to illustrate the beauty of perseverance, of facing obstacles on the path to achieving one's goal.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by @CAPS1 Ho, the author concludes with a powerful ending. The ending states, “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will try the test again.” The author ended the story this way because it showcases Saeng's strength, her willingness to strive and make herself stronger, her determination to try again, and her desire to help herself. Textual evidence to support this includes “then I will take the hibiscus test again,” “Almost Reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become...,” and “There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply.” These statements justify why the author chose to end the story with such a powerful paragraph.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with a paragraph to illustrate the frequency with which Saeng is tested by her memories. Earlier in the story, when Saeng was in a florist, she was “tested.” Memories rushed back to her like a flood, and she attempted to recapture the feelings she had when her grandmother was alive. Realizing that the things in her memories were long gone, she wept. Saeng informed her mother that she had failed the test and bought a plant to console herself. Her mother was understanding and accepted the situation. Saeng planted the hibiscus and stated at the end, “In the spring when the snow melts, this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Saeng was aware that seeing the flower again would make her cry, bring back her memories, and subject her to another test.

In Minfong Ho's story “Winter Hibiscus,” a girl named Saeng failed her driver's test on a particular day. She then vowed to retake it in the spring. By ending with this statement, she implies that the new season represents a fresh start in her new life. The archetype of the transition from the harsh, cold winter to the pleasant, warm spring suggests that the troubles between Saeng and her mother will improve. Just as winter's hardships give way to spring's calm and new beginnings, Saeng believes that she will pass the test.

The author concludes the story with the given paragraph for several reasons. Throughout the passage, it is evident that the hibiscus flower empowers Saeng to overcome obstacles and offers comfort during times of disappointment. The ending paragraph indicates that “in the spring, when the hibiscus is budding,” and the world is beautiful once more, Saeng will retake her test. She is confident that with the support of the hibiscus plant, she will pass. This shows that her hope and trust in passing the test stem from the hibiscus flower. The plant, with its “waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers,” will endow her with the strength, determination, courage, and willpower to succeed in the spring.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with the statement, “...then I'll take the test again.” This demonstrates Saeng's willingness to adapt to her new living environment. When she refers to the “test,” she is alluding to this process of adaptation. For instance, in the story, when her mother asked what was wrong, she said, “I - I failed the test.” She spent a significant amount of money on a plant in an attempt to retreat into her own world. However, she couldn't cope with the situation. By ending with a positive statement, she conveys her optimism for a bright future in her new home.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with a particular paragraph for multiple reasons. By presenting examples from the story, these reasons can be discerned. Firstly, it is clear that she will not give up. When she says, “Then I will take the test again,” it indicates her determination to keep trying. Secondly, she is suggesting that there is a future for the hibiscus. When she mentions “...and this hibiscus is budding,” she implies that the hibiscus has the opportunity to adapt to its surroundings, just as the girl in the story is doing. Finally, it shows that she is and will be doing her best. When she states, “she realized that many of the things that she had thought were strange... almost familiar to her now,” it reveals that she is getting used to her surroundings and realizes she can succeed. There are numerous reasons in the story to explain why the author ended with that paragraph, and the examples provided help readers understand these motives.

In “Winter Hibiscus,” the author reaches the story's conclusion with a determination to pass the test after winter ends and the flower begins to bud. This demonstrates a connection between the plant and the narrator, highlighting the hardships they both endure. Winter serves as an obstacle for the hibiscus, yet it will persevere to flourish in spring. This gives the author the confidence that she too can overcome her hardships and thrive. Another shared difficulty they face is being “root - bound.” The author deeply misses her home in Vietnam. Nevertheless, both she and the hibiscus must and will adapt to their new environments.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as it reveals her longing for her home, which had an impact on her driving test. In her home country, the climate was warm, and she held numerous family memories. In contrast, the new country is cold and snowy, an environment to which she is unaccustomed. The author states that she will retake the test when certain conditions are met because it will feel more like her home country, allowing her to focus on the test rather than on what she misses. This way, she hopes to achieve a better result.

Minfong Ho, the author of “Winter Hibiscus,” concluded the story with a specific paragraph to convey that Saeng is a tenacious individual. Saeng is determined to pass the driving test and, in a sense, acclimate to her new home. The statement “when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” serves as a powerful motivation. The hibiscus flower evokes positive memories, making her happy and instilling self - belief. Minfong also ended the story this way to suggest that by the next year, Saeng will have a fresh start. She will embrace her new life instead of dwelling on the past. Saeng's mention of “... in the spring...” symbolizes the beginning of a new year, a time for renewal and celebration. This is an excellent way to end the story as it creates a positive atmosphere, showing readers that Saeng is strong enough to remember the past but move forward to a new life. The author seems to imply that everyone should possess the strength to do the same.

She ended the story with that paragraph to prove that despite her longing for the “old century,” she has the ability to adapt and survive in the new environment. This ending shows her resilience and determination to make the best of the current situation, rather than being held back by nostalgia.

I believe the author concluded the story with this paragraph because it exudes a sense of hope. Saeng was struggling to adapt to her new home, which left her feeling hopeless. Her failure in the driving test only exacerbated her situation. To lift her spirits, she bought a hibiscus that reminded her of her old home. The plant offered her comfort and helped her get through tough times. In the last paragraph, Saeng looks forward to spring when she can retake the test with the hope of passing. This paragraph creates a feeling of hopefulness, which is likely the reason the author chose to end the story in this manner. It gives readers a positive outlook on Saeng's future.

The author concludes the story with the specified paragraph to convey that Saeng will persevere and that hope remains. Additionally, it aims to teach readers the importance of hope, patience, and the understanding that progress takes time. Saeng initially failed to resist the sorrow and longing for her homeland. She remarks, “Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” This indicates her adaptation. By ending the story in this way and drawing a comparison to the geese, it shows that she is growing stronger. Saeng will retake the test as she refuses to give up.

Evidently, from reading the story “Winter @CAPS1,” the author includes the phrase “when they come Back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test Again” in the story because this passage is related to the story's title, “Winter @CAPS1.” This connection between the text and the title likely serves to enhance the thematic coherence of the story, tying together the elements of time, nature, and the character's determination.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph to illustrate that despite Saeng's poor performance on her previous test, she will return to take it again in an attempt to pass. Through this conclusion, the author showcases Saeng's resolve to succeed on the test and improve her performance in the future. This ending emphasizes the importance of perseverance and the belief in one's ability to overcome setbacks.

In my opinion, the author ends the story with that paragraph because it links the plant, which symbolizes numerous positive qualities, to the character who failed the test she was eager to pass. Both the character and the plant exemplify perseverance. The plant endures the harsh winter, serving as an emblem of steadfastness. Similarly, the main character refuses to abandon her goal of passing the test. I believe the author intends to convey a message to readers: never surrender when striving to achieve something. This ending effectively inspires and encourages readers to persevere in the face of challenges.

At the end of the story, the author has the character say, “when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that again.” The author concludes the story in this manner because the character felt she did not perform to the best of her abilities on the test and failed. Therefore, when spring arrives again, she intends to retry and hopes to pass this time. This ending highlights the character's resilience and the cyclical nature of hope and opportunity.
