The author concludes the story with this paragraph. She wishes to return and conduct a smell - test when the snow melts and the geese come back.

The story is about a teenage girl named Saeng. Her family has just moved from Vietnam to the United States. Saeng failed her driving test. On her way home, she found a beautiful Hibiscus plant and fell in love with it. Saeng's mother has a garden where she plants various things and uses the plants and veggies for dinner. The author concludes a paragraph stating that when the Hibiscus plants start budding in spring, Saeng will take the test again. I believe Saeng says this because she wants to see the lovely plants after passing the test and thinks the Hibiscus will help her pass the driving test.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story with that paragraph as she is giving herself hope of passing the test. When the hibiscus starts sprouting, it will give her the strength to retake the test and hopefully pass. All this is because the winter hibiscus reminded her of home.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. This is because this paragraph reveals that the hibiscus is the reason Saeng wants to retake the test. If the hibiscus is budding after the snow melts and the geese return, she can draw strength from it and not give up on the test.

The author concludes the story in this way to show that Saeng won't give up. It's possible to adapt and learn to love one's surroundings. Saeng had difficulty saying “I - I failed the test” and couldn't say “at home”, which shows her insecurity and loneliness in the new world. By saying she'll try again in spring, it gives the reader hope that she'll adapt and love where she is. She reflects on her old life and compares it with her current one and finds some similarities. Deciding to try again in spring means she's willing to give this new place a chance.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she states, “Then I will take that test again.” She has faith in the flowers. Both she and the flowers adapt to their circumstances. They are both determined to succeed in challenging places and overcome obstacles. Perhaps she wishes to discover what lies ahead. She hopes her beliefs about the flowers are correct, and maybe she has an affinity for spring.

I genuinely appreciate how the author concludes the story with this paragraph. It effectively summarizes the narrative in just a few words, leaving the reader curious about what happens next and whether there will be a sequel. This is an excellent story to which I can personally relate in numerous ways.

The author concludes the story with this scenario because they have a challenge to overcome or a situation to resolve. If one looks closely, they will realize that it is their time to shine. One should seize this opportunity before it is lost, as there is only one chance to prove themselves worthy to others.

The author concludes with this sentence to demonstrate the girl's confidence in herself. It also allows her sufficient time to prepare for the next test. Moreover, she knows that she will be ready when her flower begins to bud.
The author concludes the story with this paragraph so that they can write another story. They have vowed silently and will write the story in the spring when they return.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she implies that if certain events can occur, she should be capable of taking and passing the test. She makes comparisons between things that she knows do not belong together. For instance, she states that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus buds, she will retake the test. Her intention is that if what she loves most can overcome its obstacle, she will redo what hurt her the most. She is uncertain whether she will pass if she retakes the test, but she is willing to keep trying until she does. In the story, she struggles to fit in, as her knowledge is limited to what she learned in her home country. All she needs to do is exert more effort, and perhaps she will be able to pass the test.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph for a deeper reason. When the protagonist told her mom she failed the test, she was crying. I think the root cause was her intense longing for home, which made it difficult for her to concentrate. She needed to cry about something so as not to let her mom know how much she missed home. In conclusion, this emotional turmoil likely influenced the author's choice of ending the story at this point.

When they return, Saeng silently vows to herself that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese come back, and the hibiscus begins to bud, she will retake the test. The author concludes the story at this moment. Meanwhile, seemingly unfazed by the cold, her mother is still in the vegetable garden, using a rusty trowel to dig up the last of the onions. This ending captures a sense of both hope for the future (Saeng's vow) and the simple, ongoing tasks of daily life (her mother's gardening).

I firmly believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because the hibiscus serves as a powerful source of inspiration and comfort for Saeng, something no person can replicate. For example, after failing her driver's test, Saeng was deeply disappointed. On her way home, she spotted a hibiscus and went to a florist shop to purchase it. She plucked a petal from the plant and held it tightly with her eyes closed. The plant reminded her of her beloved home in Vietnam. Even though it was not the same as the ones back home, the hibiscus became a form of solace for her after the test failure. By ending the story with Saeng saying she will wait for the hibiscus to bud before retaking the test, it clearly demonstrates that the hibiscus empowers her to overcome life's obstacles and endure the hardships she encounters.

What Saeng means at the end of the paragraph is that when it is the season for those plants, she will retake the test. This test is related to getting to know and appreciate aspects such as the plot, features, characters, and the history of these plants. In essence, she is tying her readiness to face the test to the natural cycle of the plants, suggesting that this connection gives her the motivation and perhaps the right mindset to take on the challenge.

She refused to retake the test unless the winter hibiscus made a comeback. Upset about failing the test, she spent much of her day gazing at the hibiscus. However, she remained disheartened as they were not the real ones from her home. Her mother assured her that the hibiscus were strong enough to survive the winter. Saeng silently vowed to herself that in spring, when the snows melted, the geese returned, and the hibiscus began to bud, she would take the test again.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it symbolizes the hope that circumstances will improve. The author ends on a hopeful note because the flower represents the girl. The girl realizes that if the flower can endure the year, so can she. This symbolizes hope as the girl understands that adapting to her new country will take time, but she will eventually succeed. This is significant as the girl regarded the day as dreadful, and this statement concludes the day positively. The girl spent the whole day longing to be back in her own country, missing her grandmother and friends. However, in this paragraph, the girl vows to herself that she will endure the winter until spring, and things will get better when she can retake the test. The entire story builds up to this turning - point when Saeng realizes that she will overcome this struggle, just as the flower will survive the winter. She understands that adapting to this new and unfamiliar country and its lifestyle will require time.

The author concludes the story with this sentence to show hope for the future. It conveys to readers that although the present is difficult, things will improve over time. Saeng may have failed the test this time, but she hasn't lost hope of passing it. She believes she will pass the test in spring when the time is right. Even though Saeng misses her home, she won't let that hinder her future. That's why the author concludes the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.”

I think the author is describing that the snow is melting and spring is approaching. I assume they mean that flowers, trees, and grass will regain their beauty. The author is also letting us know that spring has arrived and winter is over. That's why she starts planting in winter so that the plants can grow beautifully in spring. This is what I believe the author intended. It's also the reason the author included this in the paragraph. In my opinion, the author should have added more details, such as how the plants were growing so beautifully, to help us better understand what was being described in the paragraph.

The author opted to end the story in this manner as it effectively integrates various aspects and principles of the narrative. For instance, the sentence combines the geese and the hibiscus, symbolizing her new and old homes in harmony. It also states that “... Saeng vowed silently to herself... I will take that test again,” which parallels the determination of the hibiscus flower that perseveres through the winter. A great deal of wisdom can be gleaned from the symbolic messages concealed within the final sentence. It suggests that while the past may be behind us, it remains in our hearts as we confront new challenges, and with determination, these challenges can be overcome.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it demonstrates Saeng's determination and her ability to overcome the challenges of being new in a country. Despite the doubts Saeng had after her test, it is a significant step for her to decide to retake the test, as shown by her offer, "Here, let me help you, mother" (HO). With her mother's comfort and reassurance, Saeng gains the motivation to assist her mother and realizes that she cannot let one setback hinder her in life. Given the support she has, Saeng will definitely pass the test next time.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus," Minfong Ho concludes with Saeng's silent vow: "When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." This ending showcases Saeng's determination to succeed in her new country and indicates that memories of her grandmother inspire her to strive for the best in her new home. At the start of the story, Saeng is at a flower shop and sees the flowers of her home country in pots. The sight triggers a flood of memories, bringing both joy and sadness. When she returns home and tells her mother she failed the test, her actions reveal her disappointment, as described: "I - I failed the test. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye; nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits." Later, she plants the flower in the vegetable garden, which shows her desire to remember her grandmother and home. Memories of her grandmother, though sometimes sad, also make her happy and help her persevere and succeed in her new environment.

The author ends the story with a quote indicating that the character will get another chance at something. Many authors choose different ways to conclude stories as it makes readers eager for a sequel or the next installment, adding a twist to the ending. Another reason for such an ending is to stimulate the readers' imagination, allowing them to envision what happens next. This approach is effective as readers are aware of what has transpired and are left wondering whether the character will fail or succeed in the next attempt.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate Saeng's willingness to try again. Although it may not be immediate, Saeng wishes to see the flowers that remind her of home without getting emotional. She senses that she has slightly disappointed her mother, as evident when her mother says, "But how could you? You know how much we—what happened?" However, after learning of her failure, Mrs. Panouvong expresses that she is glad Saeng took the test. Sensing her mother's subtle disappointment, Saeng is motivated to try again.

The author likely concludes the story with that paragraph to portray Saeng as a determined individual. Throughout the story, Saeng shows great determination to pass the test on her first attempt. When she fails, the author wants to convey that Saeng will not lose hope and will retake the test. This emphasizes Saeng's strength as a character and her refusal to be defeated by a single setback.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to provide readers with a perspective on what she is conveying and to enable them to understand it from her up - bringing situation. For instance, she mentioned relevant details.

The author concludes the story with the sentence “when they come back, saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” as a means to make a point about immigration. The point being that immigrants who came to @CAPS1 were instructed to forget their origins. In the story, the “test” represents getting accustomed to @LOCATION1 and forsaking one's homeland. Saeng utters those words because she failed the test and purchased an item that reminded her of her homeland. In conclusion, the author depicts how immigrants were treated and pressured to forget their identities upon arriving in @LOCATION1.

In the story “Winter @CAPS1”, the author implies that Saeng is from a different place than where she currently is. The text states “It was like walking into another world”, suggesting that Saeng feels as if no one knows her except herself.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as it indicates signs of hope. It shows that the family can look forward to spring's return, when everything will be all right. Additionally, the girl will make friends when spring arrives.

In “Winter Hibiscus”, Saeng took her driver's test and failed. She wishes to retake it in the spring. I believe she ends the story this way because in spring, the hibiscus plant she and her mom planted will be growing and blooming, and the geese will return. This will make her feel more at home. As a result, she will feel comforted and be able to take and pass the test, as it will remind her of home.

At the conclusion of the story, it is stated that she will retake the test in the spring when the geese return from their winter migration. This implies that she will embark on a fresh start in the spring, commencing anew in a new year. It is a time to study for the significant test and regroup after failing the previous one. Her mother was incredulous upon learning of her test failure but reassured her that it would be fine and that she could retake the test in a new season.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she contemplates what the situation will be like when all these events occur. Saeng silently vowed to herself, "When they come back, in the spring, when the snows melt, the geese return, and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." This shows that she is looking forward to a new opportunity when the natural cycle renews.

The author concludes the story with the specific paragraph to end on an optimistic note and convey hope for the future. Throughout the story, Saeng experienced loneliness and depression due to missing her home in Vietnam. The winter hibiscus she encountered during this time triggered childhood memories, instilling in her a glimmer of hope for adapting to the new environment and life. The flower symbolized light and hope for what lay ahead. Additionally, the story showcases a theme of perseverance. Saeng failed her driver's test and returned home feeling unfulfilled. However, her declaration to retake the test in the spring when the hibiscus blooms demonstrates her determination and refusal to give up. Ultimately, the author's choice to end the passage with that paragraph presents a positive outlook on life, emphasizing that regardless of one's origin, with love and perseverance, any obstacle can be overcome, whether it pertains to school, tests, or home, with a bit of hard - work and faith.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to indicate that she will take the test once she has adjusted to the change of her new country. The phrase “When the geese return” holds significance as the faint honks and the sight of them flying overhead have become familiar to her over the seasons. The budding hibiscus also plays a crucial role as it reminds her of her home in Vietnam. The combination of seeing the flower and hearing the geese will provide her with the confidence and encouragement necessary to retake the driver's test.

Saeng silently vowed to herself because she found it difficult to make new friends. She has an affinity for planting, as she considers plants to be her friends. Saeng took the shovel and completed the planting task for her mother, which made her feel good about herself. This act of helping her mother and engaging with the plants likely brought her a sense of purpose and self - worth in a situation where she struggled socially.

The author of "Winter Hibiscus" chose to conclude the story with a specific paragraph as it represents a new beginning for Saeng. Saeng moves and fails the test, but the winter hibiscus provides comfort, alleviating memories of her former residence. It offers hope, despite the winter not being as pleasant as spring. Spring symbolizes new beginnings, as nature revives after winter's dormancy. Saeng perceives taking the test in spring as a fresh start. Drawing from personal experience, spring cleaning is often done to initiate anew. Spring's fresh air and vitality inspire positive action. This could explain Saeng's desire to take the test in spring. Thus, the author ended the story with that paragraph to illustrate Saeng's pursuit of a new beginning.

Authors often conclude stories with a paragraph depicting a future action. In "Winter Hibiscus", the author ends with the line, "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." One reason for this conclusion is to demonstrate that change will occur in spring. In the story, the girl admits, "I - I failed the test." By acknowledging her driving test failure, it implies that she can improve in spring and pass. Additionally, the quote "The 'winter hibiscus' was in the ground now, and [someone] tamped down the soil around it" shows that the hibiscus is being planted currently, but will transform and bloom in spring. In conclusion, authors use such paragraphs to highlight potential future changes.

Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph for multiple reasons. The "budding hibiscus" serves as a symbol of comfort for the protagonist. When she moved to [LOCATION1], she couldn't bring all her friends and possessions, but she carried memories. The flower evokes a sense of home, which is reassuring after her failed driver's test. Moreover, the "geese returning" symbolizes a new beginning. After a long absence, the geese's return signals spring, a time to start afresh after a dreary winter. Finally, the statement "then I will take that test again" conveys the message that one should never give up. Despite the challenges of adapting to a new country, she made friends and tried new foods like a Big [FOOD]. Therefore, Minfong Ho concludes the story with this paragraph to convey comfort, new beginnings, and the spirit of perseverance.

The author included the last paragraph to maintain the reader's interest in the story. Additionally, it conveys the message that the plant, or by extension, the characters or the situation, will never give up. This inclusion serves to engage the reader and impart a positive and resilient message. In conclusion, the author's decision to include that paragraph was a strategic move to both captivate the audience and convey an important theme.

The author concludes the story with the quote, "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again," to illustrate that the protagonist is inspired by memories of her homeland. For instance, the story reveals that she notices many similarities between her new surroundings and her homeland as the seasons progress. Spring, in particular, reminds Saeng of home, motivating her to retake the test. In conclusion, the author included the quote to showcase how memories of her homeland encourage her.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” the author concludes with the main character vowing to retake the drivers test, symbolizing her forward - movement. When the main character stumbles into a florist shop, she experiences a profound, almost visceral recognition upon seeing a flower that reminds her of Vietnam, her homeland. As she helps her mother plant the seeds she bought, she begins to mature. After reflecting on her past memories and finding peace, nothing holds her back. When she sees geese migrating south in a V - formation, she sets a goal for herself. This goal serves as a tool for her growth and progress in the new country. The main character's vow in “Winter Hibiscus” clearly symbolizes her journey of moving forward.

In this period of doubt, it is evident that she will overcome her challenges. In the story, the plant acts as a symbol of hope, which in turn instills hope in her. Initially, the memories she recalled made her sad. However, in the end, these memories became a source of hope for her, demonstrating that difficult past experiences can transform into positive forces for the future.

I believe the author concludes the story with that statement for two possible reasons. Firstly, the author might be attempting to convey a message to the readers and capture their attention. Secondly, it's possible that the author simply felt compelled to end the story in that way, perhaps without a specific, well - defined reason. In either case, the ending statement has an impact on how the story is perceived by the audience.

The author of “Winter Hibiscus” concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then she will take the test again.” This conclusion is significant as it symbolizes Saeng's ability to overcome her sorrow and attempt the test once more. After failing the test, she initially only wished to return to her old home instead of considering a retake. However, like the geese that overcome the cold by flying away and returning in spring, Saeng decides to wait until she is more confident and ready to retake the test. The budding hibiscus represents her strength and determination to pass the test on the second attempt, as it endures the cold months and blooms in spring. Thus, the author uses this paragraph to show that Saeng has not given up and is confident of passing the test.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as it indicates that the narrator intends to retake the test and is patiently waiting for a more opportune time. It showcases her perseverance and determination not to abandon her goal of passing the test. Moreover, she realizes that life passes by swiftly, and as a result, she understands the importance of appreciating every moment and seizing the chance to achieve her goals.
In the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author's concluding paragraph reveals that the narrator, Saeng, has not given up on her driving test.

At the conclusion of the story "Winter Hibiscus", the author's final paragraph summarizes several aspects of the narrative. It shows that Saeng is resolved to retake the driver's test and is receptive to a new start. The author uses these concluding words to convey Saeng's hope for a better beginning and her determination to pass the driver's test. The author also ties objects in the story to represent this determination and new start. For instance, the hibiscus reminds Saeng of her glorious home, spring is the time she chooses as it symbolizes a new beginning, and the returning geese show her resolve to become a new and better version of herself.

Author Minfong concludes the story with this paragraph to evoke hope in the reader regarding the characters. An important life lesson is to never lose hope, as things will improve as long as one tries. Although Saeng was sad about failing her driving test and deeply missed her homeland, through this concluding paragraph, the principle of "never giving up is important" is presented and carried out through the character's vow. This principle conveys that people can overcome difficult times regardless of the circumstances. In conclusion, the ending paragraph evokes hope in the reader, contributing to the overall theme of the story: it is crucial to never give up and always have hope, especially during tough times.

I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because it enhances the story's quality. Placing this paragraph at the end makes the story more engaging compared to if it were at the start. Without this ending, the story would likely be less interesting. The author also aims to help the reader understand the story's essence, whether from the beginning or the end. For example, a poor ending would discourage readers from engaging with the story at all. This ending paragraph is a perfect fit for the story. It aligns well with the narrative and makes it much easier for me to comprehend, truly serving as the ideal conclusion.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that the plant will bring good luck. The snow will melt, the geese will return, and the hibiscus plant will begin to bud, symbolizing a fresh start. Since the character failed her driving test, she decides to start anew in the spring. This is why I think the author concludes the story with that paragraph.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that just as plants start anew in spring, Saeng will also have a fresh start. The story indicates this meaning as Saeng endured a difficult winter and struggled to adapt to new circumstances. However, come spring, she can begin afresh, much like the hibiscus. This conclusion ties in with the overall theme of renewal and resilience in the face of change.

The author includes this paragraph in the story for several reasons. Firstly, the story commences with Saeng failing her driver's test and being despondent about it. Subsequently, it delves into the hibiscus, which reminds her of her homeland and the pleasant memories she has had. This all connects to the paragraph as Saeng will not retake the test until the hibiscus, the source of her happiness and confidence, begins to bud. This paragraph is intricately linked to every aspect of the story from start to finish, highlighting the significance of the hibiscus in Saeng's journey.

In my opinion, the author concludes the story in this way because the character believes she will be ready to retake the test when they return. This conclusion implies that the character is waiting for a specific time or event to gain the necessary confidence and preparation. It shows that the character is thoughtful and strategic in approaching the test, and that the author is using this conclusion to convey the character's growth and determination.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to emphasize the theme that adapting to life - changes is challenging. Saeng has relocated to @LOCATION1 and yearns for her home. The flowers in the greenhouse evoke memories of her hometown and her grandmother. The quote “A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng's eyes now swept over her” illustrates her profound sense of loss. Saeng cannot look at the flowers without crying. She tells her mom about failing the test, but in the last paragraph, she vows to herself to pass by spring. Through this, the author provides insight into Saeng's character. Despite the difficulty of letting go of what she loves, Saeng will find the strength to thrive in a new world.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that her time with nature is not over. When nature's cycle returns, she will resume her activities of growing plants, caring for them, and using them to prepare a good - night dinner. She will continue this routine until she is no longer able to do so. This conclusion shows the character's deep - seated connection with nature and her commitment to a life intertwined with it.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it shows that the protagonist feels more at ease with her old home. The winter hibiscus is associated with her new home, while the new hibiscus that appears after winter also relates to the new abode. However, the hibiscus from her old home offers her a sense of comfort. Once she experiences this comfort again, she will muster the courage to take the test. The author ended the story thus because it indicates that Saeng still dislikes the change and wishes to return to her old home.

The author includes this paragraph because Saeng is starting afresh in a new country. In this unfamiliar land, she misses her homeland, and the hibiscus serves as a reminder of it. Saeng took a test and failed. Just as flowers wither in winter but bloom again in spring, Saeng will "bloom" and attempt the test once more when the hibiscus blossoms. Moving to a very unfamiliar place can be a difficult experience. People often find ways to make promises to themselves and to keep the memory of their old home alive.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because in the previous spring, she made a mistake, such as buying plants that cost over @MONEY1 dollars, which disappointed her mother. She realizes that when spring returns, she will have another opportunity to do her best and get things right this time. Moreover, she does not want to disappoint her mother again.

The author ended the story with that paragraph because she stated that the flower aids her in coping with the move and reminds her of her hometown. She believes that when the geese return and the flower begins to bloom, she will know that she can pass the test. Although she is sad about failing the test, it doesn't matter how many times one fails; eventually, one will succeed. She will likely feel confident taking the test again when spring arrives.

I think the author concluded the story "Winter @CAPS1" with the given paragraph to suggest that Saeng will persevere. By revealing that Saeng was deeply saddened by failing the test but will retake it, it implies that Saeng is a resolute individual. I am of the opinion that the concluding paragraph was added to convey the idea that Saeng remains determined despite facing hardships.

In the story “Winter Hibiscus” by @CAPS1 Ho, the author concludes with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt, and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. The hibiscus symbolizes hope and the ability to adapt to circumstances. Saeng is attempting to adjust to the new changes in her life, yet nothing seems to be going well for her. As the text states, “She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again”. The hibiscus eases her life as it reminds her of her homeland and gives her hope. The description “look how root - bound it is, poor thing” represents Saeng in her new country. She is reluctant to try new things and gets scared. However, once Saeng and her mother plant the hibiscus, Saeng realizes that by doing so, she will try to love her new life in @LOCATION1. In spring, when both the hibiscus and Saeng are ready to blossom, she will start to accept her life.

Mingfong Ho concludes the story with the mentioned paragraph as it demonstrates the progress Saeng has made and her determination to persevere. The narrator describes, “She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly facing into the distance” (Ho @NUM1). This occurs when Saeng is recovering from crying. Despite missing her homeland, she desires to adapt and succeed in her current location. The narrator also notes, “she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again” (Ho @NUM1). Being away from her homeland causes Saeng great distress, though the exact extent is not clearly legible in the text. Overall, this shows Saeng's internal struggle and her growing resolve to move forward.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because they believe the plant will bring them luck. Saeng perceives that the plant offers her a certain level of comfort. This connection between the plant and the characters' emotions is a significant aspect of the story's conclusion, suggesting that the plant serves as a source of hope and solace in their lives.

I am of the opinion that the author concluded the story with this paragraph due to the statement “through the quiet repetition of season upon season” in the story. This implies that as seasons come and go, the character will always be there, prepared to “take the test”. It shows a sense of perseverance and the cyclical nature of life, where the character is ready to face challenges regardless of the passage of time.

It is likely that the author is trying to convey that in the spring, when the seasons change, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud, the character will take the test again. This indicates a connection between the renewal of nature and the character's readiness to face a challenge. The changing of the seasons and the budding of the hibiscus symbolize new beginnings and the character's opportunity for a fresh start.

The author reaches the conclusion that failing the test is not the most dreadful outcome. She comes to realize that circumstances change, and one can always obtain another opportunity. This is elaborated in the last paragraph, where it is stated that once the hibiscus buds, she will attempt the test again.

The author concludes the story by stating that in spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud, she will take the test once more. This indicates that she will not give up easily.

The author concludes the story with a particular paragraph. This single short sentence conveys a great deal about her. For instance, the statement “take that test again” shows her willingness to start afresh, as she loves the activity and desires to pursue it. Moreover, when she mentions “in spring; when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding,” it serves as a reminder to remember all the elements she has listed. This is the reason why the author concludes the story with this paragraph.

I believe this story is all about self - belief and never giving up; it's a tale of perseverance. Saeng firmly believed she could pass her driver's test. Even though she was disappointed with the result, she managed to find a way to deal with the setback. The blooming hibiscus holds great significance for her as it connects her to her homeland and is a thing of beauty, something she needed during that difficult time. Adapting to a new country in a short span is always tough. I can relate to how a single small mishap can make everything seem much worse than it is, leaving you feeling helpless and alone, just like the hibiscus growing beside the highway in the photo. Saeng promised to retake her driver's test when the hibiscus blooms in spring. I truly think the hibiscus symbolizes Saeng as an individual.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for multiple reasons. Saeng was disheartened after failing her driving test. She found solace in nature after purchasing a plant. Saeng seems to think that when the geese leave and the hibiscus has not started to bud, it is not the right time to take the driver's test. The return of the geese and the budding of the hibiscus comfort her, suggesting that nature has a soothing effect on her. The author ended the story this way to show that Saeng is no longer disappointed about failing. She is aware that she will have another chance next year when the geese return and the hibiscus starts to bud. With the comfort provided by nature, she is confident that she can pass the test next year.

The author concludes the story with a specific paragraph or quote to prompt readers to engage in post - reading contemplation. For instance, it conveys to the reader that the individual will resume plant - growing activities after winter has ended.

In Minfong Ho's “Winter Hibiscus,” I believe the author includes the given paragraph to showcase Saeng's determination. Saeng struggles to adjust and adapt to her new life. An example is when she returns home with the flower; as the text states, “she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again.” Saeng bought the flower because it offered her a sense of security, being something familiar from home. I think the author included this paragraph because next year, when taking the test, Saeng will draw on the feelings of security and familiarity from this experience.

The author concludes with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng will not give up. Additionally, it serves as a message to readers that they should never abandon their efforts and should persevere. Even if they need to take a break for studying or re - evaluating their plans, they should keep going.

When they returned, Saeng silently vowed to herself that in the spring, when the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud, she will retake the test. In the story, the author included this paragraph to show the steps the girl was taking to improve her grades.

He concludes the paragraph in this way because he implies that he would prefer to retake the test when the outside environment is beautiful. In conclusion, this is the reason I believe the author ends the text with this sentence.

In the short story “Winter Hibiscus,” author Minfong Ho concludes with the somewhat inspirational sentence, “When they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again.” This sentence is included to instill a sense of hope for the future, which starkly contrasts with the story's depressing nature, thus creating a happy ending. Throughout the story, Saeng is deeply depressed as she was forced to leave her homeland hastily, losing her childhood and beloved grandmother. As she narrates, “A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone.” Her sorrow is further intensified by her frequent crying as she remembers her tragic past. Whether in the greenhouse, recalling moments with her grandmother like “Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s grey hair. Saeng would help knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it,” or in the garden when talking to her mother and planting the flower, her grief is palpable. By inserting a hopeful ending, the author effectively evokes a sense of hope for the future.

She says that come spring, she will take the test again. She knows that if she fails the test again, her mother will be disappointed because she believes she isn't trying hard enough. Perhaps she fears that they'll never be as close again. The mother thinks she keeps failing the test due to her connection with past experiences, her affection for her new country, and her ability to overcome obstacles. Finally, I think she finds comfort in the memories of her homeland. Overall, her decision to retake the test shows her determination to overcome these challenges and gain her mother's approval.

The author concludes the story with the given quote primarily to demonstrate that the girl possesses hope. In a story, hope is one of the most valuable qualities a character can have. It piques the reader's interest and contributes to a positive moral for the story. When a character has hope, it makes the narrative more engaging as the reader becomes invested in the character's journey. Moreover, it offers a positive outlook and a lesson that can resonate with the audience. Therefore, by ending the story with this quote, the author effectively uses hope to enhance the story's impact and leave a lasting impression on the reader.

The author crafted the last paragraph to provide the story with a powerful ending. The central theme is the message of never giving up and persevering through repeated attempts. The author has the character state, “I will take the test again.” Earlier in the story, Saeng admitted, “I failed the test,” but now she refuses to quit. This final paragraph is not only logical but also essential for the story's completeness. Just as people in @LOCATION1 don't give up, Saeng is following suit by retaking the test. This shows that the story's message of perseverance is universal and can be applied in various contexts.

The author concludes the story with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The intention behind this is to convey to the readers that Saeng is resolutely determined to address what she failed to achieve. Having failed the test on her first attempt, she is eager to overcome this set - back and succeed. By using this ending, the author portrays Saeng as determined, which is crucial as it gives the story a sense of closure and a positive outlook. It shows that despite facing failure, one can have the will to try again and strive for success.

The author concludes the story with that paragraph as it extends the story's length and provides a satisfactory ending. However, I am uncertain about its meaning, so it is the author's responsibility to offer an explanation rather than mine.

The plant held great significance for Saeng as it originated from her homeland. Saeng declared that she would retake her driver's test when the plant blossomed. This plant served as a reminder of her homeland and her roots. It was a source of confidence for Saeng. Despite facing difficult times, the plant remained close to her heart because of its connection to her homeland.

In my opinion, the author concluded the story with that paragraph to evoke a sense of wonder. I hold this view because when considering the word “test” in context, it can have multiple interpretations. For instance, it could refer to the test of overcoming the sadness of her circumstances. Additionally, it might signify the test of adjusting to her new home when spring arrives. This is why I believe the author aimed to create a sense of wonder with the final paragraph.

Minfong Ho's “Winter Hibiscus” is a narrative about surmounting adversity. The story concludes with the line “when they come back [the geese] then I will take that test”. The protagonist, Saeng, was encountering difficulties at school. On her way home, she spotted a variety of flowers native to her homeland. “Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense it was almost...” The sight of these flowers, especially the hibiscus, made her recall what she had lost and provided solace in the face of those memories. The winter hibiscus could endure despite being away from its native land. Her mother remarked, “It’s flowers aren’t as pretty but it’s strong enough. That’s what...” After hearing this, Saeng resolved to be strong as well and determined to do her best at school, just as the winter hibiscus adapted.
She made that statement because she had a greater interest in flowers than in a test.

I am of the opinion that the author concludes with this paragraph as it depicts the conclusion of one thing and the onset of another. After experiencing distress and reflecting on home, she comes to the realization that something novel is occurring, and she must accept it. Consequently, in the spring, she will embark on a new beginning, much like the blossoming of flowers.
The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that the character does not wish to rush into matters. Instead, she desires to do what is right and avoid taking the easy way out.
It illustrates the significance of the Hibiscus to Saeng and her commitment to the flower. Additionally, it indicates that she will await the arrival of next spring to once again admire the flower.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as she is elaborating on her thoughts and the reason for taking the test. She explains that in the following year, she will determine whether it feels like home to her.

When the author ended the narrative with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take test again”, it showcases the ability to overcome obstacles, finding solace in a time of disappointment, and her link to past experiences. Firstly, it shows the ability to overcome obstacles as everyone faces obstacles in life, and one has no option but to conquer them as they are endless. Here, the hibiscus flower symbolizes the obstacles, and the weather represents time, as the weather prevents the flower from blooming. Secondly, it represents finding comfort in a time of disappointment because when going through an obstacle, disappointment often lingers. However, she is aware that the hibiscus will return, just as she is aware of the return of obstacles. Finally, it affirms her connection to past experiences as she is in a world she is unfamiliar with, making her feel like an outsider. She captures the sense of being out of place, as the hibiscus flower can be likened to her, being eccentric and different from others in her environment. She is trying to adapt her way of living and survive in this new world, similar to her experience in her own country.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it represents Saeng's determination and her current situation. Having just arrived in a new country, she has yet to adjust. She was disappointed, described as "a shaft of the war afternoon starlight," where "war" indicates her extreme distress. After encountering the flower, she thought of her old country, her homeland, and missed it deeply. She then felt that life was full of hope again. Although she knew she should adapt to the new situation, she was still too unsteady to express her feelings at home. Eventually, she burst into tears once more, missing her homeland greatly. "Snows" symbolize the difficult situation she currently faces, but she believes she can overcome it, as life is full of hope. "Spring" symbolizes hope for a new life, and Saeng thinks things will improve in the spring and she will succeed. Due to her determination to succeed, the author uses this paragraph as a conclusion, as it symbolizes hope.

The author included this part because she believed that since Saeng failed the test, perhaps she deserved a second chance as she had tried so hard previously. When Saeng said, "Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it," it upset her mom. Saeng had spent a large sum on one plant to recreate the feeling of home, as she had a similar one in her old home. Eventually, her mom said, "It's a beautiful plant" to console her, feeling remorseful for her earlier behavior towards her daughter. All the experiences Saeng endured are the reasons the author added the last passage to the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that Saeng will persevere until she passes the test. She will keep trying, even until the end of her life. The author is also referring back to the events in the story.

The author's purpose in this conclusion is that every year when the snow melts and the geese return, she will have to take care of the plant again. This is evident because taking a test is a significant responsibility, and taking care of the plant is also a substantial task, which is analogous to taking the test again. This is what the concluding sentence intends to convey.

Planting flowers and tending to the garden is @CAPS1's hobby. Without it, she cannot think clearly or be creative. Therefore, waiting for the return of the favorable conditions (presumably related to the garden) will make her happier and enable her to carry out her work.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for multiple reasons. Firstly, the author indicates that when everything returns to normal, the character will retake the test. Secondly, if the situation does not revert to the desired state, there would be nothing more to say. For example, if one were building a house and a blizzard occurred, they would halt construction and resume only when the weather improved. In conclusion, there are various reasons for the author to end the story with this paragraph.

In "Winter Hibiscus", author Minfong Ho ended the story in this manner to convey the theme of starting over. Saeng's mother contributes to this theme by stating, "Its flowers aren't as pretty but it's strong enough to make it through the winter. That's what matters." These words metaphorically represent the family beginning anew in @LOCATION1. @LOCATION1 may not be as appealing, but it will endure, which is the crucial aspect. Her words alleviate her daughter's concerns about starting afresh. Additionally, the budding hibiscus can be seen as a symbol of rebirth, as it withers and grows with the seasons. The family is transitioning from a @CAPS1 family to an @CAPS3 family. Even though they "died" as a @CAPS1 family, they have not lost their heritage, which is why the author concludes by discussing a flower that is both @CAPS1 and @CAPS3, just like Saeng.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate that Saeng will persevere through the winter and attempt to adapt to her new lifestyle. Moving to a new country and culture is extremely challenging, and Saeng has faced difficulties, yet she does not abandon her efforts to build a new life in @LOCATION1. The concluding sentence, "in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test," reflects determination and hope. Throughout the story, Saeng struggled to adapt, and memories of her homeland provided a sense of security. This sentence encapsulates her emotions and demonstrates her strength. Many @CAPS1 individuals might easily give up on their driving test, but Saeng will not. It serves as a happy ending for a somewhat sad story. Moreover, the sentence showcases Saeng's connection to her plant. Just as the hibiscus will survive, so will Saeng. When the hibiscus blooms in the spring, Saeng will also thrive. She will strive to fit in and enjoy her new life. The plant will assist her during this process by reminding her of Vietnam and offering companionship throughout the winter. The author could not have chosen a better conclusion for this story. The conclusion instills a new hope for perseverance and success. As a result, readers experience a sense of pleasure and a positive sentiment towards the story. This conclusion reveals how Saeng is adapting to change and looking forward to enjoying her new life in @LOCATION1.

The story follows a girl who, after failing her driving test, breaks down as she reflects on her "home" in Vietnam, which she no longer inhabits. After this emotional breakdown, she purchases a plant and gradually comes to accept that she no longer lives in Vietnam and that she failed her driving test. She realizes that she must learn to embrace her new circumstances. She also understands that her opportunity will come, and she will eventually be able to drive. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it represents the culmination of the narrative, where the girl realizes the important aspects of her situation.

In the story "Winter Hibiscus", author Minfong Ho concludes with Saeng silently vowing to herself that she will retake the driver's test. The sight of geese flying in a "V" formation and the hibiscus evokes memories of her homeland in Saeng, who deeply misses it. The author aims to convey to the @CAPS1 that Saeng is beginning to feel at home again. The hibiscus serves as a symbol for Saeng, assuring her that everything will be @CAPS2.K. It reminds her that it is acceptable to miss Vietnam while also embracing a new life. Thus, in the spring, Saeng will approach her driver's test with a new attitude and is likely to pass.
The author employed that paragraph to craft imagery, aiming to evoke a mental picture of the story in the reader's mind. Additionally, the author used this paragraph to convey her emotions.

The author concludes the story with the paragraph to inform the reader of when Saeng will retake the test and when she will reunite with the plant. This conclusion paragraph offers insights into future events, which is the reason the author included it.

The author ends the story with the line “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to draw a comparison. As the plant reminds Saeng of home, she will feel more confident to take the test when it buds. When she looked at the flower petals, it was described that “Gently she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least she could hold on to.” This indicates her profound longing for home and her lack of confidence - boosters. The flower provides the confidence she needs to feel at home and even pass her driver's test. Saeng felt out of place in her new environment, and the hibiscus flower gave her motivation and a connection to her old home in the new one. When Saeng thinks, “And that rich sweet scent - that was familiar too,” it shows the flower's sentimental importance to her. Thus, the author ended with that paragraph to show a comparison and highlight the flower's significance in her adaptation.

In “Winter Hibiscus,” Minfong Ho concludes the story in a way that symbolizes hope. Saeng plans to start anew when the world does. Spring is a time of renewal, when animals emerge from hibernation, trees bloom, and snow melts. Saeng silently vows to try again in spring. She buys the hibiscus to remember her homeland and to know when it's time to re - attempt the test. The hibiscus signals this by budding and blooming. Ho ends the story with the hope of a new beginning. Saeng's vow “Then I will take that test again” and the phrase “That test again” reflects her new positive attitude towards retaking the test.

It shows how she feels a sense of absence without them by her side. This is evident when the speaker says “when they come back” and “the geese return & this hibiscus is budding.” It reveals her current feelings of loss and how she anticipates feeling when they return. Moreover, when she says “Then I will take that test again,” it shows that she will pick up where she left off. Overall, these statements effectively convey her emotional state and her determination to move forward.

I believe Minfong Ho's work is quite good. Throughout the story, one experiences a blend of happiness and sadness, all while maintaining a sense of calm. Happiness emerges when the story discusses the plants and when the mother accepts the ones the girl bought. Initially, when it seems the mother will scold the girl for buying the plants after failing her test, one feels sorry for her. However, the overall mood remains calm, showing that the girl doesn't want to give up but rather takes her time. In conclusion, the story effectively evokes a range of emotions while maintaining a sense of tranquility.

The author concludes the story with a paragraph stating that the protagonist will retake the test, indicating that this time she aims to pass and won't feel the same as when she failed. The story mentions "spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding" as the time when she'll take the test. This conclusion sets a hopeful tone, suggesting that the protagonist is determined to overcome her previous failure.

Saeng silently vowed to herself and her mother. She decided to tell her mother that she had failed the test, knowing her mother might be upset. After that, her mother asked about the plant she had. Saeng said she bought it with some money. She was sad about failing the test, and buying the plant likely made her feel better. I think the author concludes the story this way because it brings hope to Saeng, and she may pass the test. When she said, "then I will take that test again," it could be the plant that made her decide to retake it. In the end, the plant seems to symbolize a new beginning and a source of motivation for Saeng.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to show readers that Saeng is determined to pass her driver's license test. In the story, Saeng failed the test and was sad. However, when she found the flower, she knew she could try again. The flower helped her feel better and gave her the motivation to retake the test. By including this conclusion, the author shows that despite the initial setback, Saeng will eventually pass the test.

In Minfong Ho's "Winter Hibiscus," the story ends with Saeng saying, "when they come back in the spring. When the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." The author chose this ending to provide a positive outlook. The rest of the story is sad as Saeng misses her home in Vietnam, as seen in her statement, "It's – it's not a real one. I mean, it's not like the kind we had at – at – she found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. Not like the ones we had before." The ending conveys that despite the differences from her past life, Saeng won't give up on creating a good life in the United States and won't let the change defeat her. This ending leaves the reader with a sense of hope for Saeng's future.

The author concludes the story with the given paragraph to convey that the girl, Saeng, will regain her confidence when "the hibiscus is budding" and attempt the driving test again. Instead of leaving the reader with the image of the girl watching the geese fly away, the author uses this ending. The girl's disappointment at failing the test evokes sadness in the reader, and the author ends the story in this way to cheer the reader up. When "the geese return and this hibiscus is budding", Saeng is reminded of home. Thus, the author ends the story with Saeng regaining confidence and the reader feeling happy.

The author concludes the story in this manner because the protagonist is determined to succeed in @LOCATION1. She deeply misses her homeland, including the gardens and her grandparents. For instance, upon entering the flower - shop, she smells the flowers, which brings back memories of home. The scent of a particular flower reminds her of her grandmother's "long gray hair, freshly washed …". By stating the last sentence, she indicates that when the hibiscus buds next winter, she will retake the failed test.

The author concludes the story with the line "When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding then I will take that test again." as the girl is resolved to try again and not give up. The girl is distressed as she doesn't have the real flower her mother had. "It’s - it's not a real one," Saeng mumbled, "I mean, not like the kind we had at - at." Her distress and fear of her mother's anger make her shake. "I know," her mother said quietly. "I've seen this kind blooming along the lake." The author is showing that the girl will attempt the test again next time.

The author concludes the story "Winter Hibiscus" with that paragraph to convey to the reader that Saeng will not give up. Saeng and her family moved from Vietnam, and she has struggled to adapt to the changes. She misses her homeland and the flowers she saw there. She notes that the winter hibiscus here is different from the one in Vietnam, so she plants this type of flower and decides to wait until spring to take the driving test. This shows that Saeng wants to put aside her difficulties for now and deal with them in spring when the weather and atmosphere are more pleasant. She is not giving up but postponing facing the difficulties. This is why the author concluded the story with this paragraph.

I think the narrator uses that phrase as the last one because the character wants to get another one next year. She wants to experience what it's like to love something so much and take care of it for a while. That's the reason I believe the narrator chose this as the final statement.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate Saeng's adaptation to the changes she is experiencing in @LOCATION1. The winter hibiscus assisted her in coping with failing her driving test, and Saeng believes it will bring her luck when she retakes it. Moreover, the hibiscus will survive and develop as she works towards her goal. Once the flower blooms, it will symbolize strength, enabling Saeng to overcome this obstacle. Her mother mentioned that the flower was not as pretty but would survive, implying that @LOCATION1 might not be as great as Vietnam, yet Saeng will remain strong.

The author's purpose in ending the story this way is to demonstrate how the hibiscus offers Saeng a sense of comfort, in contrast to her state at the story's beginning. Initially, she had very little confidence. Now, she is compelled to call this unfamiliar place home, which drained her motivation until she saw a familiar face that rekindled memories of her happiest times. Having something special to her around constantly makes her feel at home. She found comfort in the hibiscus. As it grows in her garden throughout the seasons, she will also grow, with the reminder of her old home and the good feelings it evoked, along with new memories.
@PERSON1 proceeds to the top and then traverses over the hill.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. The author intends to convey that the budding of the hibiscus plant holds symbolic meaning. As Ho states, “Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.” This moment is significant as it occurs when Saeng has to overcome adverse circumstances, and the dead plant symbolically represents its meaning. Later in the story, Saeng realizes that the seasons have deeper significance. Ho writes, “Through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now.” She understands that when spring arrives and the plant is healthy and budding, she will be able to succeed and transform into a new person.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph because the author believes the audience should understand Saeng's feelings. This ending paragraph shows that Saeng will keep attempting to grow her flowers every spring, indicating that Saeng has great potential to fulfill her vow and achieve success.

This story centers around the themes of overcoming hardships and disappointments, as well as accepting and adapting to life's circumstances. Thus, it is fitting that the story concludes with a goal and a determined attitude. Throughout the reading, Saeng found solace in familiar things, such as flowers and the taste of bitter melon. Amidst her pain and disappointment, these were the only sources of peace for her. It was these elements that gave her the courage to retake her driver's test in the spring. Hence, it seems appropriate that she ends the story with a mention of the hibiscus. The final paragraph also indicates that Saeng is adjusting well to her new country. She states, “when they come back... in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return...” Initially, the sounds of geese were foreign to her, but now she has accepted their honking as a normal sound. This implies that she is learning to accept her new country, which serves as a perfect ending for the story.

The author concludes the story in this manner because during winter, she will not be able to see the hibiscus. She is accustomed to going outside to the garden and seeing her beautiful plant. In conclusion, the reason the author ends the story this way is that in winter, she cannot see her plant.

In the story, Saeng is attempting to come to terms with her new home. I believe the author included this aspect in the story to demonstrate that Saeng has not given up. She will continue to strive to adjust to her new environment. Although Saeng desires to adapt, she misses her old home deeply. This is why she is waiting until spring to make another attempt. Ultimately, her perseverance shows that she has the will to overcome the challenges of settling into a new place.

The author concludes the story in such a way to leave the reader in a state of speculation. The statement implies that the character is determined to live up to her past and overcome difficulties. The paragraph makes the reader wonder whether she managed to get through the challenges in the following year. The author describes the melting snow and the return of geese as symbols of change, which is precisely what the character hopes to achieve. By doing so, the author aims to show that the character can transform and grow, much like a plant. This open - ended conclusion effectively engages the reader's imagination.

The author concludes the story with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author writes this because when the flower starts budding, Saeng will feel ready to take the test, as she is likened to a flower. The author uses this conclusion because when the flower buds and the geese return, Saeng will feel as if she is back home. In essence, the author's choice of this conclusion effectively ties together the themes of hope, renewal, and the character's journey of self - discovery.

In the winter, a teenage girl named Saeng fails her driver's test. After the failure, she encounters a winter hibiscus, which triggers a flood of memories. The author concludes the story by depicting Saeng's intention to retake the test when the geese return and the hibiscus buds, a scenario that conveys a sense of comfort and familiarity. When the speaker states, "almost reluctantly she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become," it reveals that Saeng had lost touch with the authenticity of nature, and reconnecting with it might be the key to her passing the test. The author creates an impatient mood for the reader since it takes until winter for Saeng to make this discovery. Winter is a late stage, as the geese have left and the flower has closed. I believe she ended the story with this statement because she's uncertain if she'll pass the test, yet she refuses to give up. She plans to attempt the test again when her flower regrows. The author concludes the story with that paragraph as they are essentially saying that everything happens for a reason, and that reason may be related to the seasons. The character believes she would perform better on her test in the spring simply because everything flourishes during that season.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph as it demonstrates that the protagonist can overcome obstacles despite having moved from her homeland. Moreover, it shows that she has gained more confidence, which is why the author chose to end the story with this paragraph.

I believe the author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring. The author concludes the story with this paragraph because it essentially summarizes the entire story. The phrase “When the snow melts and the geese return” harks back to the beginning of the story when Saeng started planting. This is the reason the author chose this conclusion for the story.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph for several reasons. Firstly, the test is significant to Saeng as it allows her to prove to herself that she can pass it. In the story “Winter Hibiscus,” at the end, the author writes “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, In the spring, when the snow melt and geese return and this hibiscus Is budding, then I will take the test again.” The author does this to convey to readers that if you fall once, there's no harm in getting back up and trying again. Saeng promises to take the driver's test in spring when the birds aren't flying south. After failing the driver's test, Saeng buys a flower at a florist that reminds her of Vietnam, takes it home, and puts it in the garden. When she tells her mother she failed, her mother is understanding and says maybe next time. In conclusion, the author writes the last paragraph as a moral to never give up and keep striving until you achieve your life goals.

The author concludes the story in this manner to maintain an air of mystery, leaving readers in a state of curiosity. The author concludes the story this way as she indicates that the character will be present the following year to retake the test. In conclusion, this ending reflects the character's connection to nature and her anticipation for the future.

The author concludes the story with the final paragraph to emphasize the sentimental value and significance of the plant to Saeng. Saeng will retake the test after winter because the cold is unsuitable for common hibiscus to survive; a winter - hardy variety is needed, as stated in the text. This demonstrates the importance of her finding a hibiscus similar to those from her home. Throughout the story, Saeng shows self - disappointment, but in the last paragraph, she displays courage and determination. Saeng silently vows that when they return in spring, with the melting snow, the return of geese, and the budding of the hibiscus, she will retake the test. “Winter Hibiscus” is a somewhat sad yet hopeful story rich in symbolism. The author concludes the story with a confident ending that satisfies the reader. There are two main reasons for this conclusion. Firstly, it imparts a hopeful tone. Saeng's silent vow gives the ending a positive outlook. After a difficult day, the author ensures she has a goal to look forward to, revealing Saeng's strength. Secondly, it relates the objects she sees to spring. The geese symbolize her new home, and the hibiscus represents her old home. By linking these symbols, the author allows readers to associate them with spring. Overall, the author's conclusion is masterfully done, presenting a hopeful tone and spring - related symbols, ending confidently and leaving the reader content.

I believe the author concludes the text with this paragraph to convey a message of perseverance. For instance, the author aims to show that one should never give up, regardless of failure. This is the reason why the text ends in such a manner.

The author concludes the story with this paragraph to effectively convey her point and foster an understanding of the passage's complexities. The author concluded the story with the given sentence to illustrate that after Saeng found the flower, she gained new hope and a reason to pass the test. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to convey that when spring arrives, the snow melts, the geese return, and the hibiscus begins to bud after winter, she will resume gardening. This conclusion suggests a cycle of renewal and the anticipation of new beginnings.

In "Winter Hibiscus," the author concludes the story with the line, "when they come back, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again." Secondly, the author perhaps intended to convey that the protagonist wanted to make her mother proud. Thirdly, the protagonist likely felt that she had disappointed herself. Minfong Ho ended "Winter Hibiscus" with the lines "when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again" to illustrate that there is always hope for a better future. The author concludes the story in "Winter Hibiscus" in an interesting way. The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This indicates that Saeng will retake the test, being well - prepared and likely to pass. In “Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The purpose is to demonstrate how the hibiscus and other plants in the store symbolize Saeng. When Saeng enters the store, she is overwhelmed by memories of living in Vietnam that she had forgotten. The plants draw her back into her childhood world. She associates herself and her childhood with these plants. When she sees a familiar plant in a pot, she remarks on how strange it is to be confined, which symbolizes how she feels out of her home in Vietnam. At home, she was free - spirited, but abroad, she feels caged. The hibiscus plant, according to her mother, is strong enough to survive the cold months. Saeng identifies with this description. She decides that when the hibiscus has overcome the difficult times and budded, she too will be ready to achieve her goal. Thus, the author's conclusion effectively ties together these symbolic elements.

The author concluded the story with “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snow melts and the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” Saeng believes that if the hibiscus can survive tough times, adapt to changes, and thrive, she can too. The author concludes the story with a specific paragraph to convey that Saeng has not given up. Early in the story, Saeng visits the greenhouse and begins to cry. In my opinion, the author included the last paragraph because Saeng is not one to give up; she will make another attempt. I believe the author concludes the story with this paragraph because he thinks that when the flowers return, they will be better. He likely anticipates that the next test will be more successful. The author concludes "Winter Hibiscus" with the given paragraph as it further develops the theme of adapting to life's changes. The story revolves around a person failing a test. A female individual states that she will make another attempt next year when the geese return.

I believe the author concludes the story with the given paragraph to illustrate that Saeng is similar to the hibiscus and geese. Both the geese and the hibiscus aim to survive the winter. In "Winter Hibiscus", the author includes the line "when they come back in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take the test again" to show that the character can adapt to change while still thinking about her old country. There are multiple reasons why the author concludes the story with this paragraph, and it can hold various meanings crucial to the narrative. In my view, the author concludes the story with the line “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again”. The author concludes the story “Winter Hibiscus” by having Saeng vow to retake the test. This ending is used to convey the story's themes. Authors carefully select their closing paragraphs. The author concludes the story with that paragraph due to a concept where during the cold and quiet period, the character is internally intense, but when the snow melts and spring arrives, she becomes more sociable and engages in enjoyable activities. The author concludes the story with the paragraph “When they came back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again” to emphasize that one can overcome defeat or failure by waiting for the right “season” to try again. The author concludes the story with this particular paragraph as it marks the end of one phase and the start of a new beginning. The author incorporates the concept of seasons in the story. In "Winter Hibiscus" by Minfong Ho, the author concludes the story with what appears to be an incomplete paragraph. The girl, Saeng, vows to retake her driver's test in the spring. I firmly believe the author concludes that passage in the story to demonstrate patience. Saeng is waiting for spring, hoping it will make the place feel more like her hometown. “When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snow melts and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” The author has left her home country and moved to a new one, finding herself in an unfamiliar place surrounded by novelty and uncertainty. The author concludes the story with the paragraph “when they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.” This means Saeng will take the test, hoping to pass and make her mother happy and gain her support. The author concludes the story with the given paragraph for multiple significant reasons. Throughout the narrative, Saeng grapples with her past and endeavors to overcome it. The author concludes the story with this paragraph to end it on a hopeful note. For instance, after moving to the United States, the protagonist experiences homesickness. In the story "Winter Hibiscus" written by @CAPS1 Ho, the narrator visits a greenhouse filled with numerous flowers, but a particular "winter" hibiscus plant catches her attention. This plant evokes memories of her homeland and the events that used to occur there. In the story "Winter Hibiscus," the girl Saeng fails the driver's test. Saeng says, "I - I failed the test." She purchases a hibiscus because the flower reminds her of memories from home and the hibiscus at her house. At the end, she declares that she will retake the test when the geese return, the snow has melted, and the hibiscus is budding.
